If even a single thought is impure, does one not bring ruin upon oneself?” The ministers memorialized, “We have heard that when a son leaves home to cultivate the Dao, it is already a grievous act of filial impiety. Now, Your Highness remains resolute in not returning. The king is aged and has no other heir to ascend the throne, and he worries day and night. If misfortune should befall him, who will wear mourning and hold the staff? Who will succeed to the throne? How can Your Highness be certain that you will not be criticized by your ministers or become the subject of public gossip? In this way, Your Highness may not yet have achieved the Dao, but an ill reputation will have already taken shape. We are Your Highness’s loyal subjects and cannot conceal the truth or remain silent when we see it. We beg Your Highness to consider carefully.” Hearing the ministers’ words, the prince could not help but shed tears and said, “I have long known that my father has no son to succeed him. I once asked my master, who said that this year, my father would have a son to inherit the throne. Return and report to my father that he need not worry. You may all return to court. But since I have left the secular world, how can there be any reason for me to return? As ministers and sons, you strive to be loyal but cannot fully fulfill filial piety. How much less can one who has left the world attend to the toils of their parents? If heaven grants our wishes, one day, when I attain the Dao, my parents will both become Buddhas. If not, all is determined by heaven, and I cannot prevent the criticism. Do not speak further. Return to court swiftly, fulfill your duties as loyal ministers, and assist the ruler. If, in the future, my mother bears a younger brother who comes of age to inherit the throne, he will rely on your counsel.”

The ministers, seeing that the Crown Prince would not be swayed and was determined to leave the secular world, could only bow in farewell and return to court. What became of him later? This will be revealed in the next chapter.

---

**The Crown Prince Teased on Mount Wudang**

Now, the King of Jingluo ascended the throne, and his ministers returned to court. Prostrating before the golden steps, they reported, “We journeyed to Mount Wudang and saw the Crown Prince. Though we spoke at length to persuade him, his resolve was firm as the wind passing unheard. He would not return. Seeing his unwavering intent, we informed him of Your Majesty’s lack of an heir. The Crown Prince replied that he had heard from his master that the Queen was with child and would bear a son this year to inherit the throne. Thus, we returned to report to Your Majesty.”

The King sighed upon hearing this. “If he is so steadfast in his refusal, we cannot press further. As for the claim that the Queen will bear another son, we cannot yet take it as certain. This is no fault of yours.” He then rewarded the woodcutter who had delivered the news by appointing him as a patrol officer, bestowed a catty of silver upon each minister, and granted them three days’ leave from court. The assembled officials expressed their gratitude and withdrew.

Time passed swiftly, and as spring gave way to autumn, the Queen of Jingluo indeed bore another prince. The King rejoiced and named him Xuanxu. In time, he grew to become the King of Jingluo.

---

Meanwhile, the Master, having taken leave of the court officials, returned to the mountain to cultivate in seclusion, where he remained for twenty years. Behind Mount Wudang dwelled the Mountain Saintess, who one day mused to herself, “By the Celestial Worthy’s decree, I was tasked to dwell in the mountain’s rear, secretly accompanying the Master in his cultivation and observing his conduct. Yet from the day he entered the mountain until now—twenty years have passed—he has not once broken a precept, and his merit has grown vast. Tonight, I shall transform into a beautiful woman and go to test him. If his heart stirs with desire and he consorts with me, then with my boundless divine powers, I may roam the world at will—would that not be splendid?”

With this thought, she recited a true incantation and, with a shake of her body, transformed into a woman—so fair she seemed a reincarnation of Xi Shi, or Guanyin descending from the mountain. Her golden lotuses, three inches bound, trod lightly as she swayed gracefully before the Master’s meditation platform. Feigning sorrowful weeping, she cried, “Master, for heaven’s sake, save this maid!”

The Master was seated in meditation when the sound of weeping drew near. Startled, he looked up to see a woman and asked in alarm, “Young lady, why have you come here? Night falls—you must leave at once.”

The woman replied, “My mother is ill, and I was returning home to see her when I lost my way and came here. By good fortune, I have met you, Master. Pray show mercy and allow me to stay the night. Tomorrow, I shall find my way home.”

The Master said, “This is a place of cultivation. There is only a meditation bed beneath the cliff—how could it accommodate a guest? Moreover, you are a woman, and as the saying goes, ‘Men and women should not touch in passing.’ The hour is not yet late—hasten from this place and seek lodging at the foot of the mountain. Tomorrow, you may return home. Would that not be best?”

The woman said, “I am but a woman. If I seek lodging elsewhere, it would be improper. Besides, I suffer from a chronic ailment—when I catch a chill, my stomach aches. Today, the weather is cold, and though this place is no proper lodging, I beg you, Master, to show mercy. Loosen your sash and hold me in your arms. If my old illness does not flare tonight, I shall be forever grateful for your kindness.”

The Master exclaimed, “Amitābha! What words are these? I have cultivated for twenty years. Not only have I not drawn near women, but I have not even shared a bed with men. I cannot comply with your request.”

Seeing that her teasing had no effect, the woman feigned a piteous cry, wailing, “The pain is unbearable! Master, save me!”

The Master pretended not to hear. The woman called again, “Master, a monastic should save those in disaster and aid those in peril. Why is your heart so hard as iron?”

After enduring her pleas for some time, the Master, moved by her pitiful cries, asked, “What remedy have you used in the past for your stomach pain?”

The woman replied, “When the pain is slight, my husband’s hand pressing upon it brings relief. When the pain is severe, I must press my belly to his for a time before it subsides. Now, the pain has struck, and my husband is not here. No one can press upon it for me. I beg you, Master, press upon it for me. If I may but see my mother again, I shall repay you with my life.”

The Master said, “I am a monastic. How can I touch a young woman’s body? This is impossible.”

The woman cried out again, “Master, as the saying goes, ‘Saving a life is greater than building a seven-story pagoda.’ If you do not press upon it soon, I shall surely die of pain!”

Seeing her distress, the Master relented and stepped forward, pressing upon her for a moment. The woman cried out again, “The pain is severe—pressing does not stop it. As they say, ‘Save a life to the end.’ I beg you, Master, loosen your sash and press against me for a while. The pain will then cease.”

The Master replied, “If that is the case, I would sooner die than comply.” He strode out beneath the moonlight and sighed, “I left my kingdom and cultivated for over twenty years, yet instead of encountering the Dao, I am entangled by others. This is no path to enlightenment. I should descend the mountain and seek another way.”

Having spoken thus, he paid the woman no further heed and departed, stepping down the mountain. Seeing the Master storm off in anger, the woman cried out in alarm, “I have committed a grave sin! This man has cultivated for over twenty years, and the celestial scriptures were soon to be bestowed upon him. Now I have trifled with him—if he leaves, all his past efforts will be undone. Should the Venerable Miaole of the Heavens learn of this, how shall I answer? I had better transform into an old woman and intercept him on the path to turn him back, thereby atoning for my transgression.”

With these words, she recited a true incantation, assuming the form of an old woman. She turned a rotting log into an iron pestle and, riding the clouds, hastened ahead to a spot on the path. There, she ground the pestle back and forth upon a stone. The Master, descending the mountain in fury, had just begun his journey when he saw the old woman grinding the iron pestle on the rock. He halted, pondering what use it could serve. Drawing near, he asked, “Venerable elder, I see you grinding this iron pestle here—what purpose does it serve?”

The old woman replied, “My granddaughter asked me for a sewing needle, but we have none at home. So I am grinding this iron pestle into a needle for her use.”

The Master laughed upon hearing this. “How many days will it take for an iron pestle to become a needle? Do not waste your energy.”

The old woman said, “I know it is difficult, but since I have already promised my granddaughter, how can I abandon the task halfway? With patience, it will surely be accomplished one day.”

The Master, hearing this, asked no further questions and continued on his way. Seeing that this attempt had failed to turn him back, the Celestial Mother transformed again, this time into an old man. Riding the clouds, she alighted three *li* ahead, where she took up an iron hammer in one hand and an awl in the other, boring into the rock by the path. When the Master arrived, he saw the old man drilling the rock and, not understanding his intent, approached and asked, “Elder, why are you boring into this rock with an awl?”

The old man replied, “I am too old to till several *mu* of dry fields, and there is no water to irrigate them. So I am boring a channel through this rock to bring water to the fields.”

The Master laughed and asked, “When will this be accomplished?”

The old man said, “As the saying goes, ‘With perseverance, even stone can be pierced.’ How can it not be done? I have been laboring at this for over a month. If I were to abandon it because of your words, would I not waste all my previous efforts? I shall not heed your remark but will redouble my diligence. One day, it will surely be accomplished. How could I give up halfway and forsake my past labors?”

The Master stood in contemplation for a long while. He mused to himself, “Since descending the mountain, I have witnessed two things—grinding a pestle and boring a rock—both arduous tasks. Yet neither would abandon their efforts because of a single word. I am a monastic, yet I fled in anger over a woman, casting aside my past cultivation. It would be better to return to the mountain and resume my practice, to see what may come of it.”

Having resolved this, he turned back and returned to the mountain to continue his cultivation. The Celestial Mother of the mountain, seeing that the Master’s heart had returned, was overjoyed. She resumed her true form and once more concealed herself behind the mountain, whereupon no more is said of her.

Now, the Venerable Miaole, observing from the clouds that the Master’s merit was complete and he was gradually entering the Dao, saw that he had yet to refine the viscera within his five organs. The Heavenly Venerable displayed his divine power, reciting an incantation. From the void, he summoned two sleep-inducing insects, which flew toward the Master and alighted upon him. Instantly, the Master fell into a deep slumber, oblivious to all.

The Heavenly Venerable then summoned the Belly-Slicing Spirit and handed him a sacred sword, instructing him to open the Master’s abdomen. The Belly-Slicing Spirit received the command, untied the Master’s sash, and split open his chest. He removed the intestines and placed them beneath a rock, covering them with a stone. Then, taking a strip of the Master’s robe, he fashioned it into a stomach, and a length of his sash into intestines, sewing them into place. The Heavenly Venerable then took out a pill of returning spirit and placed it in the Master’s mouth, ordering the Belly-Slicing Spirit to withdraw.

Reciting a true incantation, the Heavenly Venerable revived the Master in an instant. The Master awoke to find the Heavenly Venerable beside him. He promptly rose and bowed, saying, “This disciple has erred in failing to greet you from afar.”

The Heavenly Venerable said, “I instructed you not to sleep at night—why have you fallen asleep in broad daylight?”

The Master replied, “In the past, I felt my mind serene and did not sleep day or night. I do not know why today I suddenly grew so weary and fell into a slumber from which I could not awaken.”

The Heavenly Venerable said, “You must not do so again.”

The Master replied, “From now on, I shall reform.”

The Heavenly Venerable said, “Cultivate for a few more years, and you will surely attain the immortal rank. I bestow upon you this sacred sword—keep it with you always. Should you encounter evil demons, wield it and they shall depart.”

The Master bowed in gratitude, and the Heavenly Venerable rode away upon the clouds.

Unaware that his viscera had been replaced by the Heavenly Venerable, the Master continued his arduous cultivation day and night, sitting in meditation. Gradually, he felt his body grow lighter, and a five-colored cloud often enveloped him. Beasts from all directions came to pay homage, and day and night, he heard the sutras and the Dharma.

On this mountain, there was a child who was in truth a bamboo spirit. Since the Master had arrived to cultivate here, the spirit had listened to the Dharma morning and evening and had gained a modicum of divine power. One day, it transformed into a woman, approaching from the western path, weeping bitterly. Drawing near, she cried out to the Master, “Save me, Master!”

The Master asked, “Young lady, why have you come here?”

The woman replied, “My husband is forcing me to remarry, but I refused to comply. So I fled through the back gate, intending to return to my parents’ home.”

"I never expected to take the wrong path and end up here. The sky has grown dark, and a heavy rain pours down—there is nowhere for me to take shelter. I beg you, Master, allow me to stay the night. Tomorrow, I will leave at first light."

The Master replied, "This is a place for reciting sutras and expounding the Dharma. It would not be proper to accommodate you."

The woman paid no heed to his words and attempted to enter the meditation platform. Fearing she might be a ghost or demon, the Master raised his sacred sword, ready to strike her dead. But as he looked closely, he saw only a large bamboo stalk. Only then did the Master’s mind settle.

Time flew like an arrow, days and months like a shuttle. The Master returned to the mountain to cultivate for another twenty years.

One day, a eel spirit transformed into a woman, her body draped in mourning clothes. Weeping bitterly, she approached the Master’s meditation platform and bowed her head in reverence.

The Master asked, "Young lady, where have you come from? Why do you bow before this poor monk?"

The woman answered, "My family of six was struck by pestilence, and four have already perished. Now, only my young son remains, a child of three, lying ill in bed with no one to turn to. I have heard that you, Master, have recited sutras and expounded the Dharma on this mountain for forty years, attaining the true Way. I come humbly to seek your aid—pray, let your heart be moved with compassion. Visit my humble home and recite a volume of the true sutra. If you save my son’s life, I will be forever grateful, and in the next life, I shall repay you with boundless devotion."

Hearing this, the Master’s heart was moved with pity. He asked, "How far is the journey to your home?"

The woman replied, "Not far—only five *li* away."

The Master asked, "How many households live in your dwelling?"

The woman answered, "Only mine."

The Master said, "If yours is the only household, then I, as a monk, cannot comply with your request."

The woman replied, "As the saying goes: *To save a single life is greater than building a seven-tiered pagoda.* How could this be improper?"

The Master refused again and again.

The woman wept bitterly before the meditation platform, pleading again and again. The Master remained unmoved, sitting with downcast eyes. From noon until dusk, she wailed without cease. As the sky darkened, she said, "Master, since you refuse to descend, I have lingered here too long. Night has fallen, and I cannot return home. What am I to do?"

The Master replied, "Young lady, you may still make haste and return."

The woman said, "Master, you are steadfast in your refusal, and I dare not persist. But the main road below the mountain is one I can traverse alone—yet the mountain paths have left me lost. I beg you to guide me out, and I shall return on my own."

Hearing this, the Master had no choice but to rise from the platform. Taking up his sword, he led the woman down the mountain. Halfway there, she seized his shoulders from behind and said, "My feet ache with pain. I beg you to support me for a few steps."

The Master was startled and replied, "This poor monk has lived forty years in seclusion, never touching another. How could I support you? Walk slowly instead."

The woman said, "Master, your words are just. But my feet truly cannot carry me. If you refuse to help me down, then let us return to the mountain and spend the night at the meditation platform. Tomorrow, I shall go home alone."

The Master could not comply with either request. The woman then said, "You refuse to help me down, and you refuse to return with me. Master, I see you are no ordinary man—your bearing is noble, your features refined. My heart stirs with desire. I beg you to satisfy my longing for this moment, and then I shall return home. What say you?"

The Master made no reply, turning to leave. The woman revealed her divine power, rushing forward to seize him. With a spell of binding, she said, "I have humbled myself before you, like a falling flower with intent. Why do you remain as heartless as flowing water?"

The Master, ensnared by her, felt his body grow heavy, unable to break free. Suddenly, he remembered the sword at his waist. Drawing it forth, the woman vanished, and his spirit returned to clarity. He returned to the meditation platform without further mention.

Now, the Venerable Miaole observed from the clouds how the Master’s heart remained unmoved, his integrity unshaken. One day, as the Jade Emperor ascended his throne, the Venerable Miaole presented a memorial: "Your Majesty, a fragment of your soul has completed its cultivation, free from even the slightest worldly thought. You should swiftly dispatch divine generals to escort him to the celestial courts and grant him rank and office."

The Jade Emperor, overjoyed, commanded the Azure Dragon of the East, the Vermilion Dragon of the South, the White Dragon of the West, the Black Dragon of the North, and the Yellow Dragon of the Center to bear the Venerable Miaole’s carriage. He further ordered the Great White Star of the West to present a seal inscribed with the four characters *Master of the Jade Void*. The Banner-General Shigu was tasked with holding a flag to descend and welcome the Master.

The courtiers received their orders and departed.

One day, as the Master combed his hair upon a cliff, he suddenly reflected on his mortal form’s futility. His resolve faltered, and he ceased grooming, tossing the comb aside. After a long sigh, he gazed down at the sheer drop—over ten *zhang* deep. Just then, a celestial decree arrived, and the five dragons lifted him aloft. The Master, seeing the edict, knelt to receive it.

The decree read: "As the ancient saying goes, *Heaven fulfills the good intentions of men.* Reward follows good and evil, for the cosmos is impartial. We have witnessed Yuanxuan’s forty years of ascetic practice, untouched by even the faintest worldly thought. His sincerity is evident, and he is fit for a celestial rank. We now dispatch the five dragons to bear him, the Golden Star to hold his seal, and Shigu to carry his banner. We appoint him as the *Master of the Five Voids, Mysterious Heavenly Emperor of the North*, overseeing thirty-six celestial generals and eighty-two transformations. On the ninth day of the ninth month and the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month each year, he shall traverse the mortal realm to inspect good and evil. His original abode shall be the Palace of the Sun, with a stipend of a thousand measures of grain. He shall enter the Western Heaven to receive the precepts and ascend with his nine clans."

The Master, having heard the decree, kowtowed in gratitude. Turning to groom himself, he found his hair would not stay bound. Startled, the Venerable Miaole said, "Disciple, I did not foresee this. Once the celestial edict arrived, your mortal form could no longer be altered. How could you comb it again?"

The Master bowed in thanks. The Venerable Miaole then ascended to Heaven upon a cloud.

At dawn the next day, the Jade Emperor held court. The Venerable Miaole presented the Master before him. The Emperor asked, "Who is this?"

The Venerable replied, "This is Yuanxuan, whom I was commanded to bring from Mount Wudang to see Your Majesty."

The Jade Emperor, delighted, descended from his throne to raise the Master, inviting him to sit upon a brocade cushion. A grand imperial banquet was held to honor the assembled ministers. A decree was issued to escort the Master to the Palace of the Sun.

The following day, the Master ascended his seat in the Palace of the Sun. The gatekeepers announced the arrival of the assembled Venerables to offer congratulations. The Master received them, and as they conversed, a sudden surge of resentment from the north pierced the heavens. The Master was alarmed and asked the celestial lords, "I have only just arrived in this celestial realm. Why does this unceasing resentment rise from the north?"

The celestial lords replied, "Your Majesty is unaware—this is the resentment of the mortal realm. Emperor Sui Tang rules with tyranny, deluded and murderous. Thus, this miasma lingers."

Before they could finish, demonic vapors surged from all four directions.

The Master then asked, "And now demonic vapors arise—what is the cause?" The celestial lords replied, "These demonic vapors are the emanations of the Heavenly Emperor’s generals, who have incited chaos across the four quarters of the mortal realm. Hence, these vapors arise."

The Master said, "That both demonic and resentful qi surge toward the heavens is no auspicious sign. It cannot be tolerated long—what should be done?" The celestial lords answered, "If one possessed of divine power were to descend to the mortal realm and eradicate these two qi, the merit would be immeasurable, and the Three Realms would know peace."

The Master said, "Since these demonic vapors stem from my own generals, how could I hesitate to act? Tomorrow, I shall seek an audience with the Heavenly Emperor and descend to the mortal realm to purge these two qi. Would this not be fitting?" The celestial lords rejoiced and, taking their leave, returned to their grottoes.

The following day, the Jade Emperor ascended his throne. The Master stepped forward from the ranks, his court boots striking the ground, his ivory tablet held before his chest. He memorialized, "Yesterday, upon arriving at the Palace of the Sun, I beheld demonic and resentful qi surging from the mortal realm. Such omens are inauspicious for the celestial realm and must be eradicated. I have heard that these demonic vapors arise from my own generals, who have sown chaos across the four quarters of the mortal realm. I volunteer to descend and recall my generals, expel the perverse, and destroy the demonic, returning thereafter to present myself before Your Majesty."

The Five Emperors, upon hearing this, were greatly pleased. They bestowed upon him the Three Terraces Seven Stars Sword, a suit of golden chainmail, five hundred Fire Elixir pellets, and appointed him as the Great General Zhenwu of the Northern Direction. Three cups of imperial wine were offered, and the Master, having expressed his gratitude, departed the court.

The Master left the celestial realm and went to the Three Clarities Abbey to take leave of the Three Clarities. After exchanging greetings, the Three Clarities inquired as to his purpose. The Master recounted his audience with the Jade Emperor and his intent to descend to the mortal realm to subdue the demons. The Three Clarities asked, "Who will accompany you?" The Master replied, "I shall go alone, for I have no deputy. I have come to seek your counsel—how should I proceed?"

The Three Clarities said, "This is not difficult. During your cultivation on Mount Wudang, you once discarded your entrails beneath a cliff. Over time, infused with spiritual qi, your belly became a turtle demon and your intestines a snake demon, both of which now wreak havoc in the mortal realm. If you descend, retrieve these two creatures to serve as your generals, and you will surely succeed."

Upon hearing this, the Master bowed in farewell and rode the clouds down the mountain. Reciting an incantation, he transformed into a Daoist priest. What transpired thereafter will be revealed in the next chapter.

**The Master Descends to Subdue the Two Demons**

Now, the turtle and snake demons were one day admiring themselves in the Cave of Water and Fire. The snake said, "Brother, we were born beneath the cliffs of Mount Wudang, and for years, we have grown in might. Today, our divine powers are vast, and our transformations boundless. Yet, we lack a lady to share our joy, and this displeases me greatly."

The turtle demon replied, "Wise brother, you speak truly. Let us command the lesser demons to scour the households for beautiful women, and we shall take two for our pleasure." Delighted, the two immediately dispatched the lesser demons to investigate.

Now, Prefect Lin Biao of Caozhou had a daughter, Miss Jinju, aged eighteen, in the bloom of youth, with rosy lips and white teeth, surpassingly beautiful. Similarly, Magistrate Zhao Mo had a daughter, aged sixteen, named Jiaoniang, whose bearing was enchanting, her brows and eyes exquisitely formed. One day, the two young ladies were admiring flowers in the garden when the lesser demons spied them. They hastened back to report to the two demons, who immediately rode their demonic clouds to the scene.

Indeed, the two maidens were playing in the rear garden, their beauty beyond compare. Overjoyed, the demons displayed their powers, reciting incantations that summoned a fierce wind. The gale was so violent that faces could not be seen, and all the maidservants were blown to the ground. The two young ladies, clutching each other, attempted to flee the garden, but the demons each seized one and carried them away upon the clouds. In an instant, the wind stilled, the mist dispersed, and the maidservants, finding their mistresses gone, were struck with terror. They rushed to inform the prefect and magistrate.

The

The City God said, "Go and investigate. If it is indeed them who took the ladies, order them to return the two girls at once." The Local Deity replied, "Those two demons are insatiable in devouring humans and possess vast supernatural powers—how could they willingly return them?" The City God asked, "Then what is to be done?" The Local Deity answered, "To retrieve the two young ladies, nothing short of heavenly troops besieging the Water-Fire Cave will suffice. Perhaps then they may relent; otherwise, it will be impossible."

The City God followed this advice and immediately mustered his divine soldiers, surrounding the cave entrance of Mount Wudang with battle cries shaking the heavens. The forces then split into two divisions.

Meanwhile, the Turtle and Serpent Demons, having seized the two young ladies, returned in high spirits. They prepared a grand feast, intending to force the two maidens into marriage. Though the ladies refused even unto death, the Serpent Demon sought to devour them. The Turtle Demon said, "Brother, do not be hasty. No wonder they resist—they are sheltered daughters, suddenly snatched away by us. Their tears have not yet dried; how could they willingly wed us? Command the lesser she-demons to attend them for a month or so, and their hearts will naturally turn. Why rush? Now that they are in our cave, where could they flee?"

The Serpent Demon, greatly pleased, ordered the she-demons to serve them. As the two demons drank, battle cries erupted outside the cave. A lesser demon rushed in to report: "The City God of this prefecture, having learned that the two great kings have seized the young ladies, has led divine troops here. He demands the immediate release of the two ladies, or else he will storm the cave and leave not even a blade of grass standing!"

Enraged, the Turtle and Serpent Demons roused their demonic troops and charged out of the cave, forming ranks. The two demons cursed, "You are but a mortal official, rewarded with a post in the netherworld for your loyalty. We are born of heaven and earth, having achieved success through the Dharma. Our cave lacks mistresses, so we took the daughters of the prefect and magistrate—what concern is it of yours? How dare you besiege our cave with troops!"

The City God replied, "How bold you demons are! Born of calamity, you have brought misfortune upon the prefect and magistrate, whose petition reached my court. How could I not investigate? Release the two young ladies at once, and all will be forgiven. Refuse, and in but a moment, you will be dragged before the heavenly courts, where even your mouths will be silenced!"

The two demons, hearing this, lunged forward with their spears. The City God met them with his blade. From noon till dusk, neither side gained the upper hand. Then the two demons displayed their powers: the Turtle transformed into a great mountain, while the Serpent coiled atop it, charging forward. The City God, unable to withstand the assault, fled in defeat. The two demons did not pursue but withdrew their forces into the cave.

The City God returned to his court, deeply troubled. The Local Deity of Wudang reported, "My lord, do not despair. I have learned that the Dark Heavenly Emperor, ordered by the Jade Emperor to descend and purge demonic qi, has taken the form of a Daoist and now resides in the Three Clarities Temple. He must possess great power. My lord should seek his aid, and if he comes, these two demons will surely be subdued."

The City God, hearing this, immediately went to the Three Clarities Temple to see the Patriarch. The Patriarch asked, "City God, why have you come?" The City God replied, "This humble official has been troubled by the two demons of the Water-Fire Cave on Mount Wudang, who have abducted the daughter of Prefect Lin Biao and the daughter of Magistrate Zhao Mo. A petition reached my court, and I led troops to retrieve them, but I was no match for them. Hearing that the Emperor has descended to eliminate demons, I have come to beseech his aid, to save the lives of the two young ladies and swiftly extend his compassion."

The Patriarch replied, "Return now. I shall go to the Water-Fire Cave at once." The City God bowed in gratitude and departed.

The Patriarch recited true incantations, grasped his Seven-Star Sword, and rode the clouds straight to the Water-Fire Cave to do battle. A lesser demon reported to the two demons, who emerged from the cave. Behold the Patriarch’s appearance: in his hand, the Seven-Star Sword; upon his body, a golden-yellow armor and brocade robe; his brows clear, his eyes bright, his form radiant with golden light. Who was this divine being descended to the world? None other than the Great General Zhenwu of the Dark Heaven.

The Daoist called out loudly, "You two demons, cease your rudeness! By the Jade Emperor’s decree, I have come to subdue demons. Surrender at once to avoid heavenly execution!"

The two demons replied, "You belong to the upper realms, while we dwell in the mortal world. What grudge do we bear against you that you seek us out?"

The Patriarch said, "The heavenly law states: 'Demons who bewitch and abduct the daughters of good families, devouring human flesh and blood, shall be cast into Fengdu for five hundred years before they may become beasts again.' If you do not reflect upon yourselves, how dare you still act so insolently?"

Hearing this, the two demons flew into a rage and charged forward with their spears. The Patriarch pointed his sword, summoning the fire of Bing and Ding. The Turtle, being of water, fled at the sight of true fire; the Serpent, a fire star, feared it not and pressed forward with even greater vigor. The Patriarch then pointed his sword toward the north, summoning the water of Ren and Gui. The Serpent, seeing the true water arrive, could not withstand it and fled.

Seeing the two demons retreat, the Patriarch stormed into the cave, where he found the two young ladies weeping bitterly. He asked the reason, and the two girls recounted how they had been admiring flowers when they were seized. The Patriarch said, "Young ladies, do not weep. I am the Dark Heavenly Emperor, the True Martial General of the North. The Turtle and Serpent Demons have been driven away by me."

"Now close your eyes, and I shall send you home." The two young ladies, upon hearing this, bowed in gratitude and closed their eyes. The Patriarch intoned the true incantation and, riding two auspicious clouds, conveyed the two maidens back to Caozhou Prefecture. There, Golden Chrysanthemum was reunited with her father. Magistrate Lin asked, "You have been gone for three days, and we saw no trace of you—how is it you have returned home?"

Golden Chrysanthemum replied, "Daughter and Young Mistress Jiao’er went to the rear garden to admire the flowers when suddenly a fierce wind arose, so thick we could not see one another. We were seized by two demons from Mount Wudang—the Turtle and the Serpent. Father, you petitioned the City God, but even he could not overcome the demons. Later, the Dark Heavenly Emperor, the True Martial General of the Upper Realm, drove the two demons away, rescued us upon clouds, and brought us home, so that we might live to see you again."

The magistrate was overjoyed and asked, "What did your rescuer look like?"

The young lady answered, "When the deity arrived, he had crimson lips and white teeth, his hair flowing down his back, a fair complexion with three strands of beard, clad in a purple robe with a jade belt, and wielding the Seven-Star Sword."

Upon hearing this, the magistrate immediately left the hall to summon the judicial commissioner. After a short while, the commissioner arrived, and they exchanged greetings.

The magistrate recounted to the judicial commissioner how his daughter had been rescued by the True Martial General. The commissioner said, "Your daughter’s account matches word for word what my own daughter told me. Now that we have been saved by a heavenly deity, we ought to build a temple in gratitude."

The magistrate replied, "Your Excellency speaks rightly." He then ordered Xu Dexun to gather laborers and materials to construct a temple outside the northern gate, with three halls and five beams. A statue was sculpted of the deity—hair unbound, sword in hand. The magistrate, the commissioner, their daughters, and their households all went to offer incense and give thanks. From then on, those who prayed there found their pleas answered without fail, and the temple’s incense has never ceased burning.

Meanwhile, the two demons, driven away by the Patriarch, had nowhere to take refuge and seethed with resentment. The Serpent Demon said, "We are starving and have no shelter. Brother, why not transform yourself into a ferryboat and me into a bamboo pole? We can wait at Sanli Creek for travelers to cross. When we reach midstream, we’ll sink the boat and devour them—both a meal and a refuge. What could be better?" Delighted, the Turtle Demon transformed into a ferryboat and the Serpent into a pole, and they waited.

The Patriarch, having escorted the two young ladies home, returned to pursue the demons. Riding the clouds, he saw them disguised as a ferry and pole. A faint, cold smile crossed his lips. He halted his cloud, descended, and transformed into a Daoist priest. Stepping aboard, he seized the pole and slowly poled to midstream. The Turtle Demon rejoiced, preparing to display his power and sink the boat. But the Patriarch, seeing this, uttered a true incantation and brandished his Three Terraces Seven-Star Sword, his body swelling to ten thousand *zhang*. The Serpent, now the pole in his grasp, panicked and leapt into the water. The Turtle Demon reverted to his true form and tried to drag the Patriarch under. The Patriarch revealed his divine power—his head touched the Thirty-Three Heavens, his feet spanned the Five Lakes and Four Seas—pinning the Turtle and Serpent to the creek bed, leaving them no escape.

Seeing this, the Serpent Demon soared into the air and cried, "A celestial decree arrives!" The Patriarch, hearing of the decree, reached out to receive it. The moment he did, the Turtle Demon slipped away. Realizing he had been tricked, the Patriarch was filled with regret, but the demon was already gone. He searched along the way but found no trace.

The two demons, having escaped, conferred and hid in an old well, waiting for someone to draw water so they could seize and devour them. The local earth god was alarmed and set out to report to the Sheji, but he encountered the Patriarch on the road. The earth god knelt to greet him. The Patriarch asked, "Have you seen the whereabouts of the Turtle and Serpent Demons in this area?" The earth god replied, "The two demons are hiding in the well here, plotting to harm the villagers. I was just about to report to the Sheji." The Patriarch said, "No need. Lead me to the well." The earth god guided him there.

The Patriarch drew his Three Terraces Seven-Star Sword, recited a true incantation, and pointed at the well. The two demons emerged and confronted him. The Patriarch pointed his sword south, then north—water and fire surged forth, and the demons fled in defeat. He pursued them, but they hid within a lotus root. Seeing this, he plucked the lotus and hacked it to pieces from stem to tip. The demons, trapped inside, panicked. They shrank themselves to the size of a millet grain, but the Patriarch pried one open—there they were. They leapt to the ground and fled. The Patriarch gave chase until he reached a pomegranate tree, where he saw them hiding among the fruit. He pointed his sword from south to north—water and fire erupted, shaking the branches and leaves, casting a crimson glow. The tree, roots and all, was engulfed, and the demons, fearing water and fire, could not escape. The Patriarch chanted an incantation, and the flames and waves intensified. The Turtle, afraid of fire, and the Serpent, afraid of water, could endure no more and cried out in misery.

The Patriarch asked, "Will you surrender?" The demons answered in unison, "We willingly submit to the Heavenly Emperor." The Patriarch ceased the water and fire. The demons emerged and prostrated themselves before him. He asked, "Do you truly submit?" They replied, "We will forever follow the Heavenly Emperor and dare not rebel." The Patriarch said, "If you are sincere, reveal your true forms for me to see." At his command, the Serpent reverted to his original shape—golden scales, iron bones, and a single horn—while the Turtle’s back bore the Eight Trigrams of the Nine Palaces, with three eyes and three tails.

Seeing their true forms, the Patriarch restrained them with his Seven-Star Sword and took out two Fire Elixirs, giving one to each. He instructed, "You have just consumed my Fire Elixirs. If you ever rebel, call out ‘Fire,’ and you will perish instantly." The demons bowed in submission. The Patriarch took them to the celestial court and reported the events to the Jade Emperor. Delighted, the Jade Emperor appointed the Turtle and Serpent Demons as the Water and Fire Generals, to accompany the Patriarch in his divine work. After the Patriarch and the two demons expressed their gratitude, the Jade Emperor said, "A dark *qi* still rises from the mortal realm. Who else remains?"

"Proceed to subdue and disperse all the dark *qi*." The Patriarch stepped forward and reported, "This humble servant, though unworthy, volunteers to descend once more to the mortal realm and eradicate the dark *qi*, returning to court thereafter." The Jade Emperor, greatly pleased upon hearing this, immediately bestowed three cups of imperial wine. The Patriarch expressed his gratitude, withdrew, and with the Water and Fire Generals in tow, arrived at the Hall of the Three Pure Ones to pay homage to the Three Clarities.

Unbeknownst what would transpire next, we leave the tale here and shall reveal more in the following chapter.

In West Peace Alley of Xuzhou Prefecture lives a man named Zhan Lisheng, who has long practiced virtue and accumulated merit. He travels as a merchant, and since your attainment of the Dao, he has sculpted your likeness and offered incense in your honor. Now, he must cross the river on urgent business, but Gongming has stationed one of his generals to patrol the waters. You must descend at once to the riverbank: first, to save this man’s life and not betray the goodwill of your devotee; second, to subdue this demonic horde—would this not be a most excellent outcome?"

The Patriarch, having heard this, bowed his head in gratitude, departed from the Three Clarities Abbey, and instructed his Water and Fire Generals. With a shake of their forms, they transformed into three travelers, who hailed a boatman by the riverbank. From the mighty Yangtze, a solitary skiff drifted toward them. At its prow stood a boatman, bamboo pole in hand, guiding the vessel gently to shore. Suddenly, a gust of black qi surged forth, concealing seven figures who lunged forward to seize the Patriarch and his companions.

As the demonic qi drew near, the Patriarch revealed his divine power. Brandishing his Three Terraces Seven Stars Sword, with the Water General to his left and the Fire General to his right, he cut down the horde of demons, who fled in disarray, unable to withstand the onslaught. They scurried back into the Clear Wind Cave and reported all that had transpired. Upon hearing this, Zhao Gongming flew into a rage, donned his armor, and charged into battle. There he met the Patriarch, hurling curses without end.

Enraged, Zhao Gongming raised his iron mace and struck at the Patriarch, who met the blow with his sword. They clashed for over thirty rounds, neither gaining the upper hand. Zhao Gongming pondered for a moment, then secretly commanded his subordinate Li Bian to reveal his true form—a tiger-tailed whip with thirty-two segments, thirty-three *zhang* in length, light as a goose feather in the wielder’s hand yet crushing as Mount Tai to those struck. Displaying his divine prowess, he engaged the Patriarch in battle.

Upon seeing this, the Patriarch ordered the Serpent Spirit to manifest its true form—a serpent thirty-two *zhang* long, coiling tightly around the whip, its weight like Mount Tai, nearly crushing Li Bian to death. Gasping for breath, Li Bian transformed back into his original shape and broke free from the serpent’s coils, fleeing in haste. The Patriarch pressed the attack, and Zhao Gongming, unable to resist, abandoned the cave and fled upon a propitious cloud.

The Patriarch stormed into the cave and instructed the Tortoise and Serpent Generals: “The fiend has been routed and will surely descend forty *li* away by cloud. You two must hasten there at once. Let the Serpent Spirit transform into a great mountain, and the Tortoise Spirit into a jujube. I shall turn this Seven Stars Sword into a temple called the Tongxian Abbey. I will disguise myself as a Daoist priest, reciting scriptures within. The fiend will inevitably come to the abbey for tea. Once he drinks, you shall roll into his belly—only then can we subdue him.”

The Tortoise and Serpent Generals received their orders and, together with the Patriarch, soared upon the clouds to a place called Ten Thousand Pines Grove, where they took their positions. The Patriarch transformed into a Daoist priest and began chanting scriptures within the abbey.

Zhao Gongming, defeated by the Patriarch, fled to the Clear Wind Cave but found no refuge. Ravenous with hunger, he spotted the abbey ahead, its scripture-chanting resonant. Entering, he was led into the hall by the priest. Overcome by hunger, he demanded, “Bring me food at once!”

The priest replied, “Where have you come from, honored guest? Our noon meal is finished, and the evening repast is not yet prepared. I can only offer you tea.”

“Then bring me a cup of tea,” Zhao Gongming said, “and quickly prepare food after—I am starving.”

The Patriarch placed the Tortoise Spirit, transformed into a jujube, into the tea and offered it to Zhao Gongming, who swallowed it whole. As the jujube entered his belly, the Patriarch asked, “Zhao Gongming, do you recognize me?”

“Who are you to know my name? I do not know you,” Zhao Gongming replied.

“If you do not recognize me, then behold my true form.” The Patriarch turned and revealed his original appearance.

At the sight, Zhao Gongming attempted to flee, but the Patriarch commanded the Tortoise Spirit within him to seize his innards. Zhao Gongming cried out in agony, collapsing to the ground.

The Patriarch said, “The jujube you just ate was my general, the Tortoise Spirit in disguise. If you surrender to me, I shall give you two elixir pellets to expel him. Refuse, and you shall perish.”

Hearing this, Zhao Gongming pleaded for mercy, vowing to submit. The Patriarch handed him two Fire Elixirs to swallow, and the Tortoise Spirit emerged. Zhao Gongming bowed in submission, and the Patriarch rejoiced. Zhao Gongming then summoned his seven generals, who arrived in a subdued black qi, pledging their allegiance.

**Chapter Three: The Patriarch Faces the Golden Blade’s Peril**

It is told that the Black Tiger Spirit, a general under Zhao Gongming, seeing his master absent, transformed into a young maiden and descended to the mortal realm, concealing herself deep in the mountains. Often, she lurked by the roadside, feigning sorrowful weeping, devising countless schemes to ensnare and devour travelers. One day, she transformed into a maiden, wailing pitifully in the mud by the roadside, crying for help. When the Patriarch approached, she called out, “Save me! Save me!”

The Patriarch, accompanied by Zhao Gongming and the Water and Fire Generals, arrived to find the maiden mired in the mud, pleading for rescue. Sensing she was a demon, the Patriarch seized her with his right hand. Startled, the demoness fled in terror.

The Patriarch pursued closely, brandishing his Seven-Star Sword to point at the demon, which then revealed its true form—a great tiger with black stripes. Upon seeing it, Gongming rushed forward and struck with his whip. Recognizing its master’s arrival, the tiger knelt to the ground and begged for mercy. Gongming led the tiger before the Patriarch, who rejoiced greatly.

Meanwhile, the Jade Emperor ascended his throne as the Wondrous Music Heavenly Worthy presented his report, saying that the Patriarch had descended to the mortal realm and subdued Zhao the Killing Spirit and the Black Tiger. Delighted, the Jade Emperor commanded the Heavenly Worthy to descend with the imperial decree, bestowing upon Gongming the titles of Eminent Scholar of the Zhao Mansion, Grand Marshal of the Golden Wheel and Ruyi Enforcer, with a tiger-subduing rope in his left hand and an evil-averting whip in his right. Gongming expressed his gratitude.

The Heavenly Worthy returned to the celestial courts, while the Patriarch, accompanied by Gongming and the Water and Fire Generals, set out once more to subdue the Black Qi. Now, this Black Qi was a sand-blade spirit born from Guan Yu’s saber, known as General Jinlie. It commanded three thousand blade soldiers, all capable of assuming human form, and dwelled in Mount Tiantai. Any who passed beneath the mountain were seized, hacked to mincemeat, and devoured.

One day, as the Patriarch patrolled the Black Qi and arrived at Mount Tiantai, the blade spirit transformed into a man—tall of body but short of leg, his entire form radiating golden light. Seeing the golden glow enveloping him, the Patriarch knew it was a demon. Drawing the Three Terraces Seven Furrows Sword from his waist, he struck. The blade spirit met the attack, and they fought over a hundred rounds without victory. The blade spirit displayed its divine power, and in an instant, flying blades filled the battlefield, gradually closing in. The Patriarch could not withstand the assault; flying blades pierced his body, and he fell dead upon the field.

Seeing the Patriarch slain, the sand-blade spirit withdrew its troops and returned to Mount Tiantai.

The Water and Fire Generals and Zhao Gongming, witnessing the Patriarch’s death by blade, were filled with sorrow. The Water General said, “Brothers, our presence here is futile while we stand by helplessly. In my humble opinion, Brother Zhao should guard the Patriarch’s remains while my serpent brother and I ascend to the heavens to seek the Three Pure Ones and inquire how to revive him.”

Gongming replied, “Your plan is sound. I shall remain here while you two hasten to the heavens.” The Water and Fire Generals bid farewell to Gongming, mounted the clouds, and ascended directly to the Three Pure Ones’ abode. Prostrating before them, the Three Pure Ones inquired, “You two followed your master to the mortal realm to subdue the Black Qi. Why have you come here?”

The Tortoise and Serpent Spirits recounted the encounter with the blade spirit and its flying blades. Upon hearing this, the Three Pure Lords immediately issued a decree summoning the Wondrous Music Heavenly Worthy to their presence. After the Heavenly Worthy paid his respects, the Most High Lord Lao said, “Your disciple Xuanyuan descended to the mortal realm and encountered the sand-blade spirit, who slew him with flying blades. The Water and Fire Generals have come seeking aid. You must descend swiftly to revive your disciple and subdue the sand-blade spirit. If you delay beyond ten days, his body will dissolve into blood and water, never to be restored.”

The Heavenly Worthy assented and, accompanied by the Water and Fire Generals, took leave of the Three Pure Ones. Returning to his hall, he descended to the mortal realm and arrived at the Patriarch’s remains. Chanting true incantations, he gathered his inner spiritual qi and breathed it into the Patriarch’s mouth three times. Gradually, the Patriarch revived. Seeing his master, he turned and prostrated himself, thanking him for saving his life, and inquired about the blade spirit.

The Heavenly Worthy replied, “This is no ordinary demon but a rogue magical treasure belonging to a disciple of the Venerable Master Pu’an.” The Patriarch asked, “Who is the Venerable Master Pu’an’s disciple?”

The Heavenly Worthy answered, “A man from the Three Kingdoms era, named Guan Yu, styled Yunchang.” The Patriarch said, “I have heard that Guan Yunchang was merely a loyal and valiant warrior of the Three Kingdoms. How did he come to be deified and enter the celestial courts?”

The Heavenly Worthy replied, “You are unaware. In the mortal realm, all loyal ministers, filial sons, and those of upright and selfless conduct are recorded in the earthly registers. When their allotted years end, they ascend to the heavens, where their merits are weighed and ranks bestowed, allowing them to enjoy the rewards of celestial emolument. Such cases are not rare.

In life, Guan Yu was a man of the Three Kingdoms, unwavering in loyalty and righteousness. Betrayed by Lü Meng’s treachery, he died without yielding, his spirit dispersing in the howling yin winds before coalescing in the clouds. One night, he encountered the Venerable Master Pu’an in meditation. At the utterance of a divine word, Guan Yu descended before the altar. The Dharma Master Pu’an then received him as a disciple and administered the precepts.

One day, as Pu’an attained the Dao, he ascended to the celestial courts. The Jade Emperor enfeoffed Guan Yu as the Loyal and Righteous Great General, tasked with guarding the Heavenly Gates by day and overseeing Fengdu by night. Later, when the Tathāgata expounded the Dharma in the Western Heaven, Guan Yu learned of the sufferings of samsara. Pleading illness to his lord, he secretly accompanied Zhou Cang and Guan Ping to the Western Heaven to hear the teachings, leaving his sand-blade behind at home.

Unexpectedly, this unruly creature, seeing its master absent, descended to the mortal realm to wreak havoc. If you wish to subdue the sand-blade spirit, you must journey to the Western Heaven and summon Guan Yu himself, for only then can this object be reclaimed.”

Overjoyed, the Patriarch bid farewell to his master and instructed Zhao Gongming and the Water and Fire Generals to remain on guard. Then, mounting a propitious cloud, he set forth toward the West to seek the Tathāgata. As the Tathāgata expounded the sutras and preached the Dharma in the Thunderclap Monastery, he saw a propitious cloud approaching. Turning to Guan Yu, he said, “The Supreme Emperor faces peril and has come to seek you.”

“For what purpose have I been summoned?” asked Guan Yu.

“You shall know shortly,” replied the Tathāgata.

Before the words had faded, the Supreme Emperor entered from without and prostrated himself before the dais. The Tathāgata descended the steps to raise him, saying, “I already knew of Your Majesty’s arrival. Pray, take a seat. I have summoned Guan Yu here so that you may explain the matter in detail.”

“Very well,” said the Supreme Emperor.

The Tathāgata then called Guan Yu to appear before the Supreme Emperor. After the formalities of greeting were complete, the Patriarch recounted the affair of the sand-blade. Guan Yu replied, “If my blade has caused mischief, and Your Majesty has deigned to summon me, how could I dare refuse? Yet my heart is set on the Buddha-Dharma, and though I have heard the sutras, I have not yet attained awakening. How can I depart? Allow me to reach enlightenment first, and then I shall go.”

The Tathāgata said, “There is something you do not understand. The Supreme Emperor is a transformation of one of the Jade Emperor’s souls. Once, due to unchecked desire, he fell into the mortal realm, but now he has restored his golden body. You are his subject, and he is your lord. If the lord commands his minister to die, the minister cannot refuse; if a father orders his son to perish, the son cannot disobey. Now that he has come, how can there be any reason for you not to go?”

Guan Yu said, “If I must go, then I shall go, but I have not yet completed my study of the Dharma—how can we meet again?”

The Tathāgata replied, “Though your study is not yet complete, if you remain here and take the Supreme Emperor as your master, you shall be spared from the toils of the mortal realm for life after life. You need not listen to sutras or receive teachings to escape the suffering of samsara.”

Guan Yu, overjoyed at these words, thanked the Tathāgata. He instructed Guan Ping and Zhou Cang to return home, then turned and bowed to the Patriarch. The Patriarch was greatly pleased. Taking leave of the Tathāgata, he departed the Western Heaven with Guan Yu, descending upon clouds to meet the Water and Fire generals and Lord Gongming. All rejoiced.

At dawn the next day, Guan Yu raised a clamor before the Heavenly Terrace Mountain. The blade spirit, drinking wine in his cave, heard the uproar outside and grew furious. Donning his armor, he strode from the cave entrance. There stood Guan Yu, nine feet and three inches tall, his face like dark jujubes, clad in a green robe, seated upon his red hare steed, exuding a murderous aura. The blade spirit looked up, saw his former master, and his bones turned to jelly. Revealing his true form, he collapsed to the ground. Guan Yu stepped forward, seized him, and brought him before the Patriarch. The Patriarch was overjoyed and memorialized the Jade Emperor. An edict arrived from the Jade Emperor, appointing Guan Yu as **Lord Chongning, Daoist Perfected Sovereign of Resplendent Numinosity, Marshal of the Pass of Primordial Qi**, resuming his former duties: guarding the Heavenly Gate by day and overseeing Fengdu Hell by night, patrolling and inspecting all realms. In his left hand he held the **Golden Fierce Sand Blade**, in his right the **Purple Tenuity Edict Seal**; his left foot rested upon a **Thunder Spirit**, his right upon a **Fire Chariot**, aiding the Supreme Emperor in subduing demons. Guan Yu expressed his gratitude. What befell thereafter shall be revealed in the next chapter.

**The Patriarch Subdues the Thunder and Field Generals**

The Patriarch, having captured the sand blade spirit, continued onward with the Water, Fire, and other generals until they reached the region of Yongzhou. Suddenly, a flickering demonic aura and a sky-piercing grievance met their gaze. The Patriarch looked up to see an old man weeping bitterly as he approached. The Patriarch stepped forward and asked, “Elder, why do you weep so sorrowfully?”

The old man replied, “This is the land of Yongzhou. My name is Sun Hao, and my entire household of seven has observed the fast on the third day of the third month.”

The Patriarch asked, “Why observe the fast on the third day of the third month?”

The old man said, “I have heard that a man who cultivated the Dao on Mount Wudang has now ascended to Heaven. We seek his blessings, so we fast on his birthday.”

The Patriarch said, “Since you fast on his birthday, you are a virtuous man—no harm should befall you. Why then do you weep so bitterly today?”

The old man replied, “My weeping is not for the fast. Not far from here lies a mountain called Divine Thunder Mountain. Recently, a demon has appeared there, wearing a Daoist crown, his ghostly head bearing three eyes, wielding a hammer, and styling himself the **Newly Ascendant King**. This demon is lustful beyond measure. Whenever a local family has a maiden to be wed, they must send her to his mountain to spend the night before the wedding day—only then will she be allowed to proceed with the marriage. If they refuse, the demon emerges from the mountain and slays the entire family of the bride-to-be. I have a granddaughter named Jinlian, who is to be wed tomorrow. We had planned to send her, but she refuses to go. If she does not, my entire family will perish—hence my sorrow.”

The Patriarch said, “I possess the arts to vanquish demons. Do not weep—I shall save you.” The old man bowed in gratitude. The Patriarch instructed him to return home, maintain the fast with devotion, and prepare his granddaughter for the wedding, assuring him there was no need for concern. The old man thanked him and departed.

The Patriarch summoned Marshal Guan and ordered him to transform into a woman. The Patriarch himself took the form of an old man, and together they approached the cave entrance of Thunder God Mountain. The Newly Ascendant King, seeing the old man delivering a maiden, rejoiced and prepared to emerge from the cave to embrace her. The Patriarch let out a thunderous shout, and Marshal Guan reverted to his true form, charging into the cave. The demon, caught off guard, was seized and brought before the Patriarch. The Patriarch fed him a **Fire Elixir** and enlisted him as a general under his command.

Proceeding another thirty *li* or so, they came to a mountain called Fallen Spirit Mountain. Within it lay a cave named **Three Realizations Cave**, home to a chieftain named Tian Hua. He regularly sent lesser demons to patrol the mountain, demanding gold and silver as toll from travelers. Those who could not pay were struck dead by thunder, their bodies blown into the cave by a great wind, their hearts and livers plucked out to steep in wine. One day, as the lesser demons blocked the path ahead, the Patriarch and his company arrived. The demons demanded gold and silver as toll. Sensing the demonic aura clouding the sky, the Patriarch knew these were no ordinary bandits. Drawing his **Three Terraces Seven Stars Sword**, he struck, and the lesser demons fled. The Patriarch pursued them to the cave entrance. The demons rushed inside and reported to their lord, Tian Hua. Enraged, Tian Hua performed a spell within the cave, summoning divine thunder that flew toward the entrance. The Patriarch, seeing this, pointed his Seven Stars Sword and cried, “Halt!” The thunder stood still.

Seeing the thunder stand still, Tian Hua emerged from the cave without a word, spear in hand, and lunged at the Patriarch. Unable to withstand the Patriarch’s might, Tian Hua turned to flee back into the cave, only to be ensnared by Marshal Zhao’s flaming lasso and brought before the Patriarch. Tian Hua pleaded for mercy and pledged allegiance. The Patriarch rejoiced, offering Tian Hua a pellet of Fire Elixir to consume, and took him into his ranks. With two generals now under his command, the Patriarch drafted a memorial to the Jade Emperor. Delighted, the Jade Emperor bestowed upon Xin Xing and Tian Hua the titles of Marshal Lei Kai and Marshal Gou Bi, each wielding a command tally to accompany the Patriarch in subduing demons. Xin Xing and Tian Hua expressed their gratitude.

The Patriarch and his company continued their journey. Seventy *li* later, they encountered an old man named Zhang Wan. Seeing the Patriarch and his followers dressed as Daoists, the old man stepped forward, bowed, and inquired, “Venerable masters, where are you bound?” The Patriarch replied, “We are traveling to subdue evil.” The old man said, “If you truly possess such powers, there is a mountain near my humble abode called Tou Ge Shan. Within it dwells a demon that reveals no form but, upon spying fine goods or fair maidens, whisks them into its cave with a gust of wind. If your arts are as potent as you claim, I beg you to vanquish this fiend and rid the people of this scourge.”

The Patriarch took his leave of the old man and led his company to Dou Ge Shan, where they raised a clamor of battle cries. From the cave emerged a figure with crimson hair and tusks, wielding a wind-wheel in one hand and a great blade in the other. He charged at the Patriarch, who met him with his sword. After twenty rounds, Guang Ze, unable to overcome the Patriarch, recited a true incantation. A furious gale erupted from the wind-wheel, scattering the Patriarch’s company and hurling the Patriarch himself beyond the Thirty-Second Heaven. Startled, the Patriarch found himself before a grand hall, its plaque inscribed with the words “Hall of No-Birth.” Entering, he saw a man clad in Daoist robes and cap. The Patriarch stepped forward, bowed, and asked his name. The Daoist replied, “I am Qi Zhao, known as the Water Terrace Immortal.” The Patriarch recounted how he had been blown away while subduing the demon. The Immortal smiled faintly and said, “You are an emanation of the Golden Palace—how have you not mastered this art?” The Patriarch replied, “This humble one is truly ignorant of it.” The Immortal said, “This wind is the pure *qi* of the North Wind, harnessed by this demon to harm others. If dispersed, it would bring coolness to all under heaven. I possess a pellet, forged from the wind and fire of a thousand kalpas. Take it, and when you face battle, the wind will not move you.”

The Patriarch received the elixir, bowed in thanks, and departed the hall. Riding the clouds, he returned to Dou Ge Shan, where he reunited with his company and recounted the events. The next morning at dawn, the Patriarch placed the pellet in his mouth and challenged Guang Ze to battle. Guang Ze once more unleashed his wind-wheel, but the Patriarch stood unmoved. Stunned, Guang Ze fumbled in dismay as the company seized him. He kowtowed and pledged allegiance. The Patriarch rejoiced. A decree from the Jade Emperor arrived, appointing Guang Ze as Marshal Zhou of the Wind-Wheel to accompany the Patriarch in his Way. What befell them thereafter? Tune in to the next chapter for the resolution.

The Patriarch Subdues the Plague and Crosses Flame Mountain

Now, in Ninghai County of Shandong, there emerged a demon unseen in form, who invaded people’s dreams. He called himself Zhang Jian, spreading the plague of pox and rashes to harm the young children of households. Wherever his touch fell, he planted the seeds of pox and rashes, bringing death to families’ sons and daughters.

As the Patriarch arrived, he saw a baleful cloud descending from the sky. Within it stood a man—fair of brow and bright of eye—wearing the helmet of Erlang, herding three children before him. The Patriarch drew his Three-Terrace Seven-Star Sword and struck at Zhang Jian from midair. Enraged, Zhang Jian unsheathed his blade to meet the blow. After fifty rounds, neither gained the upper hand.

Zhang Jian cried, “I have no quarrel with you! You dwell in the upper realm, and I in the middle—why not keep to your place?”

The Patriarch replied, “You spread plague to harm the people. I have come specifically to subdue you.”

Hearing this, Zhang Jian made no reply but renewed the battle. The Patriarch summoned his company, and they surged forward as one. Overwhelmed, Zhang Jian fled into his cave and barred the entrance. The Patriarch devised a plan: he had the Serpent Spirit transform into a child, weeping at the cave’s mouth. The lesser demons seized the child and brought it before Zhang Jian, who, thinking it a captive, opened his mouth to devour it. The Serpent Spirit reverted to its true form, slithering into his belly and writhing within. Zhang Jian writhed in agony, collapsing to the ground.

From within his stomach, the Serpent Spirit spoke: “Open the cave door and welcome my master and his company. Refuse, and I will crawl inside you until you die.”

Zhang Jian hastily unbarred the entrance, admitting the Patriarch and his followers. He knelt, begging for mercy. The Patriarch was pleased. He gave Zhang Jian an elixir of fire to swallow, then bade the Serpent Spirit emerge. A decree from the Jade Emperor soon arrived, appointing Zhang Jian as Marshal Zhang of Utmost Loyalty, wielding the Plague Mallet to follow the Patriarch in his teachings and save the people. The Patriarch then departed Ninghai County.

A hundred *li* from the county stood Flame Mountain. As dusk fell, the Patriarch and his company sought rest upon its slopes when suddenly a baleful cloud arose, alarming all. From its midst emerged a demon chief wearing a Daoist crown, brandishing a Fire-Wheel Blade. Before him, a lesser demon held a crimson banner inscribed: “Great King Xie Shirong of the Water-Defying Citadel.” They descended from the sky to attack.

Generals Guan and Zhang advanced to meet them. Shirong spewed true fire—its radiance dazzling, its heat overwhelming—and the two generals were forced to retreat. Seeing his commanders falter, the Patriarch drew his Three-Terrace Seven-Star Sword to join the fray. Shirong exhaled more flames, but the Patriarch intoned a true incantation, summoning the Tortoise General. With his Six-Star Sword, he pointed north, drawing forth the true water of Kan. The deluge surged forward.

Shirong, being of fire, saw the true water approach and his flames extinguished. A chill seized his body, and he fled back into his cave, barring the entrance. Seeing Shirong refuse to emerge, the Patriarch devised another plan: he had the Tortoise Spirit transform into a lesser demon and descend from the sky to brawl with the cave’s minions before Zhang Jian’s eyes. The Tortoise Spirit then reverted to its true form, flooding the cave with water. Panicked, Shirong rushed out, only for the Patriarch to point his sword and summon the true fire of Kan—its flames billowing, engulfing the cave. Trapped within, Shirong shivered uncontrollably, while his minions wailed in despair, all drowned in the deluge. Only Shirong, half-dead from the cold, found himself cornered with no escape. Tian Hua stormed into the cave and seized him, bringing him before the Patriarch.

The Patriarch asked, “Will you surrender?”

Shirong, nearly frozen to death, had no choice but to submit. The Patriarch displayed his divine power, extracting three measures of true fire from Kan and condensing them into a pellet, which he gave Shirong to swallow. He then memorialized the Jade Emperor, who, greatly pleased, dispatched a celestial envoy bearing a decree. Shirong was appointed Fire Virtue Lord Xie, wielding a golden whip and Fire-Wheel Blade to follow the Patriarch in his teachings. Shirong expressed his gratitude, and the company departed Flame Mountain.

The Patriarch left Flame Mountain and arrived at Kunlun Mountain, where six demons—self-styled the Six Poisons of Heaven, Earth, Sun, Moon, Year, and Time—lurked within. They often lay in ambush along the roads, poisoning travelers who passed by, none escaping unscathed.

As the Patriarch neared Kunlun Mountain, he saw the demons gathering and warned his company, “These fiends are no ordinary foes. Their glow betrays poisonous qi—be on your guard.”

Before he could finish, a violent gust assailed them. The Patriarch raised his Three-Terrace Seven-Star Sword to block it, but the poisonous qi struck him full in the face, knocking him senseless. His followers scattered in terror. Moments later, the qi dissipated, and the company regrouped to search for the Patriarch. They found him collapsed, unconscious. Dismayed, Generals Guan and the others exchanged helpless glances, unable to revive him.

Guan then addressed the company: “Watch over the Patriarch’s body. I will ascend to the upper realm to seek the Three Pure Ones’ counsel.”

The others assented. Guan immediately mounted the clouds and ascended to the heavens, where he prostrated himself before the Three Pure Ones and recounted how the Patriarch had been felled by poison.

The Three Pure Ones said, “This is the work of six deputy generals under Zhu Yanfu of Kunlun Mountain, known as the Six Toxin Spirits. They unleashed their poison sack beneath the mountain to wreak havoc. To save your master, you must journey to Kunlun and summon Zhu Yanfu—only then can he be revived.”

General Guan replied, “I fear that if I go, Yanfu will refuse to save my master.”

The Three Pure Ones said, “If you go alone, he will not comply. That man possesses a treasure called the Poison Sack, most formidable indeed. We shall accompany you. First, we will revive your master, then he may go to meet Yanfu. If he refuses to submit, when your master moves to subdue the Six Toxins, you must use a stratagem to capture him.”

Overjoyed, General Guan ascended with the Three Pure Ones upon the clouds, arriving at Kunlun Mountain. There, they saw the Patriarch enveloped in toxic qi, unconscious and insensible. The Three Pure Ones recited the true incantation and waved a fan, dispersing the poisonous vapors. They sprinkled pure water over the Patriarch’s body, circling him as they did so, and exhaled three breaths upon him. The Patriarch stirred faintly, opening his eyes to see the Three Pure Ones. He immediately prostrated himself in obeisance.

The Three Pure Ones said, “You were lost to the Six Toxins’ qi. To eradicate this poison, you must ascend Kunlun’s peak and entreat Zhu Yanfu to remove it.”

The Patriarch asked, “What method shall I use to dispel it?”

The Three Pure Ones replied, “If you engage him in battle, he will surely open his Poison Sack to ensnare your generals. I possess a treasure fan called the Carefree Fan, which has endured through countless kalpas. No perverse or demonic qi dares approach it—one wave and all is vanquished. Take it and give it to your subordinate, Marshal Xie, who is originally the Star of Fire Virtue. Should you meet in battle and Yanfu opens his sack, have Marshal Xie enter it bearing my fan. Let him burn his way out with fire, and the Poison Sack will be destroyed, unable to capture you. Only then can you subdue this man. If Yanfu surrenders, return the fan to the upper realm without delay.”

The Patriarch bowed deeply in gratitude. The Three Pure Ones then mounted the clouds and returned to their celestial palace.

The Patriarch immediately instructed Marshal Xie to follow the plan. At dawn the next day, he ascended with his generals to the summit of Kunlun Mountain and entered to see Zhu Yanfu. Yanfu sat unmoving. The Patriarch stepped forward and bowed, but Yanfu, still seated, haughtily demanded, “Who comes here?”

The Patriarch replied, “I am Zhenwu, the Perfected Martial General of the North, sent by the Jade Decree to subdue the black qi below.”

Yanfu asked, “Why have you come here to subdue black qi?”

The Patriarch said, “There is a scourge of Six Toxins beneath the mountain. I hear it is caused by your subordinates, who harm the people. I ask you to subdue them.”

Yanfu retorted, “You were sent to subdue black qi, yet you oppose my generals. If you cannot subdue them, how dare you come before me?”

The Patriarch replied, “I was sent to eradicate all demonic black qi, serving the Jade Emperor and relieving the people’s suffering. Now I ask you to act—why do you speak thus?”

Yanfu snapped, “Do not speak another word of nonsense.”

"If you do not leave at once, I possess a dharma-treasure that can contain all of you—after seven days, you will dissolve into pus and water."

Upon hearing this, Marshal Xie suppressed the fire in his heart and stepped forward to curse Yanfu. Yanfu made no reply; he simply took out the Poison-Containing Bag and cast it upward. All the generals fled. Only Marshal Xie stood firm, holding his fan before the steps, and was enveloped by the bag. The Patriarch and his company turned to do battle with Yanfu. From within the bag, Marshal Xie burned his way out. Seeing the bag torn by fire, Yanfu was greatly alarmed. Marshal Xie fanned him squarely on the head, and Yanfu, unable to escape, collapsed to the ground. The generals seized him, and Yanfu surrendered in submission.

The Patriarch took a golden elixir to mend the Poison-Containing Bag, then drew forth a Fire Elixir and fed it to Yanfu. A Jade Decree descended, appointing Yanfu as Marshal Zhu, Keeper of Those Who Disbelieve in the Dao and Its Methods. He was given a golden mallet to wield and the Five-Poison Bag to carry, and ordered to follow his master in the Way.

Zhu Yanfu expressed his gratitude, then took leave of his master to descend the mountain. He stretched open the Poison-Containing Bag and gathered all Six Toxins into it before returning to the Patriarch. The Patriarch was overjoyed.

Yanfu said, "Now that I have collected all the toxic qi, I fear that in days to come, people may conflate miscellaneous perverse qi with the Six Toxins, falsely invoking my name to gather poisonous qi. I wish to eliminate those who engage in such deception."

The Patriarch replied, "Very well."

What transpires thereafter shall be revealed in the next chapter.

The Patriarch was about to set forth with his retinue when suddenly a propitious cloud descended, bearing the Star Lord of the West, Tai Bai. A jade decree arrived, which he proclaimed:

"Since you entered the Dao, We have been filled with joy. The black qi of the Middle Realm has gradually been severed. The ministers have recommended you, for you are the Water of the Northern Ren and Gui, capable of extinguishing the Fire of the Southern Bing and Ding. You are to subdue Hua Guang.
