The Patriarch expressed his gratitude and accepted the decree. He instructed his generals to accompany the Star Lord Tai Bai, and together they rode the clouds straight into the Celestial Pass, where they encountered Hua Guang. The Patriarch drew his Three Terraces Sword and shouted, "Who comes? Do not be rude!"

Hua Guang replied, "I am one who delights in this renowned place, fond of wine and women, known as the Flower-and-Wine Marshal Ma Lingguan."

The Patriarch asked, "Are you not the former Hua Guang?"

"Yes," he answered.

The Patriarch said, "What grievance have you against the Jade Emperor that you dare set fire to the Southern Heaven’s Pass?"

Hua Guang retorted, "You dwell in the North, and I burn the South—what concern is it of yours?"

The Patriarch declared, "I am here by the Jade Emperor’s decree to capture you. Surrender peacefully, or in an instant, I shall reduce you to nothing."

Hua Guang, being of a fiery nature, did not reply but instead brandished his long spear and lunged at the Patriarch. The Patriarch displayed his divine power, his head reaching the Thirty-Three Heavens and his feet spanning the Five Lakes and Four Seas. Upon seeing this, Hua Guang transformed into a being with three heads and six arms, engaging the Patriarch in fierce battle. The Patriarch rallied his generals, who charged from all sides. Hua Guang was soundly defeated and fled toward the North.

The Patriarch pursued him, but Hua Guang, seeing this, hurled his Three-Cornered Golden Brick. The Patriarch used his banner to roll it up and capture it. Frustrated, Hua Guang then unleashed his Wind and Fire Wheels, but the Patriarch seized them with his Seven-Star Sword. Panicked, Hua Guang threw his Fire Pellets, only for them to be similarly ensnared. With no escape, Hua Guang fought desperately. The Patriarch summoned the Water of the Northern Ren and Gui, overwhelming Hua Guang and pinning him to the ground with his Water-Subduing Staff, rendering him immobile.

Now, Hua Guang had originally been a pile of lamp wicks before the Tathāgata, who later recited a true mantra to transform him. He was the essence, spirit, and yin of fire, and thus, upon encountering the Water of the Northern Ren and Gui, he could not escape and was captured by the Celestial Emperor.

The Patriarch said, "You beast, ignorant of worldly affairs—what power did you possess to strike the prince? Now that you are captured, what excuse do you have?"

Pressed beneath the water, unable to move his limbs, Hua Guang wept, "This disciple was driven by Deng Hua’s coercion, forced into this act. Now that I am seized by the Celestial Emperor, I beg for your compassion and mercy."

The Patriarch replied, "If you are willing to abandon evil and return to the right path, I shall enlist you as a general under my command."

Hua Guang promptly agreed, "If the Celestial Emperor is willing to save me, I vow to submit and never rebel again."

The Patriarch then took out a Water-Gathering Pearl, transformed it into a pellet, and instructed Hua Guang to swallow it. "I shall spare you thus."

Hua Guang had no choice but to comply. The Patriarch warned, "That pellet is my Water-Gathering Pearl. If you harbor any rebellious thoughts, I shall recite the incantation, and the water in your belly will boil, reducing you to water within seven days."

Hua Guang said, "I am forever indebted to the Celestial Emperor for saving my life and shall remain at your side."

The Celestial Emperor, hearing this, lifted the Water-Subduing Staff and released Hua Guang.

Hua Guang then said, "Though you have taken me in, the Celestial Soldiers press closely to capture me. How may I escape the Celestial Court?"

The Patriarch replied, "You are a fire star—head south."

Hua Guang said, "My dharma treasures have all been taken by you. How can I go?"

The Patriarch returned his former treasures to him. Hua Guang bid farewell to the Patriarch and descended to the Middle Realm.

The Patriarch returned to the Jade Emperor and, after the customary prostrations, the Jade Emperor asked, "We summoned you to capture Hua Guang. Have you done so?"

The Patriarch replied, "Your servant has indeed subdued Hua Guang."

The Jade Emperor said, "Since you have captured him, why not bring him before Us for sentencing?"

The Patriarch petitioned, "This servant observes that Hua Guang did not rebel out of malice but was driven by circumstances. I beg Your Majesty to show mercy and allow Hua Guang to assist in the Middle Realm in subduing the black qi. If he renders merit in the future, let it offset his crimes."

The Jade Emperor assented. The Patriarch then requested permission to descend to the mortal realm to subdue the black qi. The Five Emperors, upon hearing this, were greatly pleased. They personally offered three cups of imperial wine and draped him with ceremonial silk before departing the Golden Palace.

Exiting the Southern Heaven’s Precious Virtue Pass, the Patriarch descended to the mortal realm with his generals, resuming their journey along the familiar path. They arrived at a place under the jurisdiction of Huaizhou Prefecture.

In the village, they encountered a man weeping bitterly as he approached. The Patriarch stepped forward and asked, "Venerable elder, why do you weep so?"

The man replied, "I am Li Zhoufang. In our village, two years ago, a demon appeared, visiting the dreams of the villagers. It claimed its name was Dang Guiji, its body black in hue, and demanded that we build a temple in its honor. It insisted that during the New Year and the Dragon Boat Festival, we offer it the three sacrificial animals along with wine and sweet liquor; if we refused, it would take five lives from our village each day. The villagers did not believe it at first, but true to its word, within three days, fifteen of us perished. In fear, we built a temple and made offerings, and indeed, we enjoyed a year of peace.

This year, as the Dragon Boat Festival approaches, the demon has again appeared in the villagers’ dreams, declaring that this year it does not want the three sacrificial animals or wine and sweet liquor—it demands that I send my daughter to the temple to serve it for a full year, to be released on the corresponding day next year. If I refuse, it will slaughter everyone in the village. I have only this one daughter, and if I do not send her, it will harm all the villagers. On the day of the Dragon Boat Festival, the people will come to my home to seize her and take her to the temple. I am trapped with no way out, and so I weep in despair."

The Patriarch said, "Venerable elder, do not weep. My disciples and I possess the arts to subdue this demon." Upon hearing this, Li Zhoufang bowed in gratitude.

The Patriarch said, "No need for bows. Return home in peace; all will be resolved." Zhoufang took his leave and departed.

The Patriarch then summoned Zhu Yanfu, transforming him into a maiden while he himself took the form of Li Zhoufang. He instructed them to lie in ambush beside the temple and enter it as planned. The lesser demons reported to Dang Guiji, who rejoiced and emerged from his cave, descending the steps to embrace the maiden and carry her inside. The Patriarch then revealed his true form, drawing his Seven-Star Sword, while Marshal Zhu also resumed his original shape. As Dang Guiji attempted to flee, the serpent spirit from the rack leapt down and coiled around him, pinning him to the ground. Dang Guiji cried out in misery.

The Patriarch asked, "Will you surrender?" Guiji repeatedly declared his willingness to yield. The Patriarch took out a Fire Elixir, fed it to Guiji, and set the temple ablaze. He then submitted a memorial to the Jade Emperor, who appointed Dang Guiji as the Examining Marshal of the Dang Regiment, wielding a bamboo staff and following the Patriarch to subdue demons. After Guiji expressed his gratitude, the Patriarch and his company continued on their way.

Meanwhile, the villagers, seeing the flames in the temple extinguished and no further calamities befalling them, all gazed heavenward and bowed in thanks. The Patriarch, perceiving this with his wisdom-eye, turned his cloud around and descended before the people. Li Zhoufang, along with the villagers, bowed and said, "Had it not been for Your Daoist Truth, our entire village would have perished. May we know your honorable name?"

The Patriarch wrote six characters in the air: "Northern True Martial General." Then, ascending halfway into the sky, he let his hair flow loose behind him, his feet treading upon the tortoise and serpent, his hand gripping the Three Terraces Seven-Star Sword. The people looked up and bowed deeply. In an instant, he vanished from sight.

The villagers erected a temple and enshrined the Patriarch’s statue, offering daily devotion—this need not be recounted further.

Now, in the Black Pine Forest of Xi’an Prefecture, there lived a demon named Kang Xi, who wore an Erlang helmet and bore three strands of whiskers tied with melon vines. He dwelled in Benevolent Sage Crag, stirring up malevolence. The Patriarch and his retinue arrived at Black Pine Forest, where Kang Xi transformed into a bandit blocking the path, demanding gold, treasures, and meat as toll. The Patriarch replied, “We are ascetics—where would we obtain such things?”

Kang Xi said, “If you have none, dare you call out to me three times, and I shall let you pass.”

The Patriarch declared, “If truly we possess no treasures or meat, I dare call ten times.”

No sooner had the Patriarch spoken than Kang Xi muttered an incantation, summoning a bronze bell from midair to trap him beneath it. Kang Xi then returned to his cave. The generals strove to lift the bell but could not, their hearts heavy with distress. They sent the Serpent Spirit to seek the Venerable Miaole.

The Heavenly Worthy asked the Serpent Spirit, “You follow your master to subdue demons—why have you come here?”

The Serpent Spirit recounted how their master had been ensnared by the bell. The Heavenly Worthy descended with the Serpent Spirit, intoning a true spell. Drawing a bowl of pure water, he cast it eastward, and an eastern wind blew the bell aside. The Patriarch lay lifeless within. The Heavenly Worthy placed a pellet of Returning-Soul Elixir into his mouth and exhaled upon him thrice. The Patriarch revived, bowing in gratitude.

Inquiring about the demon, the Heavenly Worthy replied, “This fiend is on intimate terms with the Smoky Daoist of the rear cave. The Daoist is not presently in his abode, and his whereabouts are unknown. I shall transform into a Daoist priest, and the Serpent Spirit into an immortal elixir. We shall deliver it to the demon—he will surely suspect nothing. Once he consumes the elixir, we shall subdue him.”

The Patriarch rejoiced and waited with his generals at the foot of Black Pine Forest. The Heavenly Worthy transformed into a Daoist priest, while the Serpent Spirit became an elixir. They approached the cave, and a lesser demon announced their arrival. Kang Xi emerged to greet them.

The Daoist priest said, “I have long admired Your Excellency’s renown. Hearing of the great king’s recent exertions, my humble cave has refined two immortal elixirs. Unworthy to consume them myself, I humbly present one to augment Your Excellency’s lifespan by a century.”

Kang Xi, overjoyed, bowed in thanks and swallowed the elixir. The Heavenly Worthy asked, “Do you recognize me?”

Kang Xi replied, “Why speak so madly? We have long been acquainted—how could I not know you?”

The Venerable Miaole declared, “I am no Daoist priest,” and revealed his true form. Kang Xi, beholding it, was struck with terror.

The Heavenly Worthy said, “You have just consumed an elixir—transformed from my Serpent Spirit. For trapping the Patriarch beneath the bell, I have come to seize you.”

Kang Xi refused to believe it. The Heavenly Worthy called out to the Serpent Spirit, who responded from within Kang Xi’s belly, slithering upward. Kang Xi clutched his stomach in agony and collapsed. The Heavenly Worthy asked, “Will you submit?”

Overcome by pain, the demon relented. The Heavenly Worthy bade the Patriarch enter the cave, retrieve a Fire Elixir, and feed it to Kang Xi, then summon the Serpent Spirit forth. The Venerable Miaole ascended on clouds to memorialize the Jade Emperor, who bestowed upon Kang Xi the title Benevolent Sage Marshal Kang, wielding a golden axe to aid the Patriarch in subduing demons—this shall be recounted later.

How the tale unfolds next shall be revealed in the following chapter. The Patriarch received a transformation from the Purple Tenuity.

Now, in a village of Guizhou Prefecture stood a bridge called the Spirit-Passing Bridge. Beneath it lay tens of thousands of ghostly soldiers who emerged at dead of night, vanishing by dawn with mournful cries. Their leader was one Pang Qiao, who wore a golden circlet upon his head. From dusk till midnight, none dared cross the bridge or sail beneath it, for any boatman who passed would be dragged into the water and devoured, his corpse never to be seen. The villagers shunned the bridge, and ferrymen refused to ply their craft.

The Patriarch arrived with his generals at the bridge’s edge as dusk fell. They rested beneath its span, and at the first watch, a chill wind howled as ghostly wails rose in the dark. The Patriarch warned, “Disciples, another demon lurks here—remain vigilant.” Before he could finish, the ghostly horde swarmed the bridge, seizing the men. The Patriarch and his followers drew their blades and struck, driving the ghosts back into the water. Tortoise and Serpent Generals, wielding the Golden Fiery Sand Blade, charged after them. The ghosts fled to report to Pang Qiao, who burst from his lair to engage the two generals. Outmatched, Tortoise and Serpent retreated to the shore, only for Pang Qiao to pursue—until he met Marshal Zhu, who clashed with him in fierce combat. The Marshal cast his Five-Poison Bag, ensnaring Pang Qiao within. Bound and brought before the Patriarch, Pang Qiao kowtowed in submission. The Patriarch fed him a Human Elixir, then memorialized the Jade Emperor. By imperial decree, Pang Qiao was named Marshal of Primal Qi, armed with a golden blade to aid the Patriarch in subduing demons.

The tale now turns elsewhere. In the heavens, the Purple Tenuity Star faced calamity, falling to the mortal realm and taking birth in the household of Elder Gao of the Western Forests. Unnoticed, time flew like an arrow, days and months like a shuttle, until fifteen years had passed. The Purple Tenuity grew into a man of striking presence, named Gao Yuan, his bearing noble and his features refined. Meanwhile, Emperor Yang of the Sui, heir to the throne, held court with his ministers. Lu Pingshu stepped forth and petitioned, “Your Majesty has no heir, only a daughter, Princess Yusheng, now come of age. You might select a consort for her as a joyous occasion—perhaps an heir may yet come.” The Emperor approved, decreeing the erection of a bridal pavilion. Gao Yuan, still unwed, heard of the imperial selection and wandered beneath the pavilion. The Princess, struck by his elegant bearing, cast down her jade silk whip, summoning him into the palace. Delighted, the Emperor named Gao Yuan her consort and held a grand feast for his ministers.

The next day, Emperor Yang ascended the throne. A messenger presented an urgent memorial: the northern barbarian king had rebelled, his armies assaulting the frontier. Enraged, the Emperor demanded counsel. Lu Pingshu advised, “Your Majesty’s newly chosen consort could lead the troops, with Yang Qinhu, son of Yang Li—peerless in valor—as vanguard. Only thus may the barbarians be repelled.” The Emperor agreed, dispatching Yang Qinhu and the consort to the front. There, the consort clashed with the barbarian general Nada’er, who proved no match for Yang Qinhu and fled in defeat. The consort pressed the attack, slaughtering countless foes until the barbarian king retreated north. Returning in triumph, the consort was received with joy, though the Emperor’s nights remained troubled by the lack of an heir. He commissioned endless rituals, yet never once ascended the altar himself, instead reveling in the palace and bleeding the realm dry.

On the seventh day of the seventh month, a star plunged into the consort’s estate, its radiance dazzling—none other than the Purple Tenuity Star. That night, the consort dreamed of ascending the Golden Palace before awakening, the star’s descent now explained. The Emperor, drinking in the palace, witnessed the spectacle and demanded, “What fell, and where?” His ministers reported it had landed in the consort’s residence. Enraged, the Emperor summoned the consort the next day. After the customary obeisance, he declared, “I chose you as consort, yet after three years, you have given me nothing. Last night, a luminous object fell into your home—clearly a demonic omen.” He ordered the consort’s execution. Terrified, Gao Yuan kowtowed and pleaded, “I am a man of the west, son of Gao Lin—how could I be a demon? Spare me, and if I bear no son within a year, I will accept my fate. I am no demon.” The Emperor’s wrath cooled, and he relented.

The consort returned home and recounted the ordeal to the Princess. Horrified, she burned incense nightly in the rear garden, praying for an heir. One day, as she dozed in the garden, the Star of Venus appeared in her dream, saying, “Your father is without the Way and deserves no heir. Your husband is a celestial star, cast down for offending the Jade Emperor—thus, you too shall have no child.” With that, the vision vanished. The Princess awoke and told the consort of the dream. Overcome, he wept, then bade her farewell and hanged himself in the rear hall. The Princess, finding him, wailed in grief and petitioned the Emperor for a proper burial, which was granted.

As for the consort, his soul drifted aimlessly until the local earth god, recognizing the fallen Purple Tenuity, prepared to escort him to the Lord of the Underworld.

Just as the earth god was about to lead him away, the Patriarch happened upon them, searching for dark qi alongside his retinue. The earth god came forth to greet them and reported the matter of the consort. The Patriarch ordered the earth god to bring the soul before him. The consort recounted all that had transpired. The Patriarch then drafted a memorial to the Jade Emperor. The Jade Emperor pardoned the Purple Tenuity’s former offenses and enfeoffed him as the Fierce-Nature Marshal Gao Yuan, Descended from the Nine Heavens, wielding a bronze sword in his left hand and a golden basin in his right, within which rested a coiled topknot of purple-gold. He was to follow the Patriarch in subduing demons. Marshal Gao expressed his gratitude and withdrew.

As for what transpired later, that shall be revealed in the next chapter.

The Patriarch Acquires the Five Thunders and Five Tones
Now, in the western lands there stood a mountain called Mount Chasi. Within it, the people had built a temple, and in that temple stood five divine statues, each with a name: Zhou Chang, Zhao Guang, Shi Ding, Liu Ze, and Pei Jian. As the Patriarch and his retinue pursued the dark qi, they suddenly encountered a great rain. Seeking shelter, they entered the temple. Just as they were about to sit, they saw malevolent qi surging. The Patriarch was startled; looking up, he saw the five statues come to life and begin brawling among themselves. As the Patriarch and his company attempted to flee the temple, the sky darkened in an instant, clouds and mist swirling, and thunder roared, shaking heaven and earth. The Patriarch found himself unable to move, his head pounding, his vision blurring, and he collapsed to the ground in a stupor. Marshal Guan, alarmed, rushed forward and carried the Patriarch out of the temple, but he remained insensible. The retinue, distressed, resolved to send Marshal Gao to ride the clouds and summon the Venerable Miaole to revive the Patriarch.

Now, the Venerable Miaole was seated in the Hall of Longevity when Marshal Gao arrived. “You follow your master in subduing demons,” he said. “Why have you come here?” Marshal Gao recounted how they had entered the temple and been struck by thunder, leaving the Patriarch unconscious. The Venerable said, “The five within the temple are the Five Thunder Gods. Only when they fight among themselves does thunder sound. Since your master has been harmed and lies insensible, you must hasten to the Eastern Heaven and summon the master of the Five Thunders to subdue this menace.” Marshal Gao asked, “Who is their master?” The Venerable replied, “The Thunder Lord is surnamed Deng, named Cheng, and styled Heavenly Lord. He resides in the Taihua Palace. Go swiftly.”

Marshal Gao took his leave of the Venerable and journeyed directly to the Taihua Palace, where he paid his respects to the Heavenly Lord Deng. The Heavenly Lord said, “I hear you accompany the Northern General in pursuing dark qi. Why have you come here?” Marshal Gao replied, “I follow my master in subduing demons. We arrived at a place where, within a temple, five deities suddenly began fighting among themselves. Thunder resounded, and my master fled the temple but fell insensible. I inquired of the Venerable, who said they are your subordinates. I beg you to issue your command to subdue the Five Thunder Gods and revive my master.” The Heavenly Lord, having heard this, descended to the mortal realm with Marshal Gao. After the retinue exchanged greetings, the Heavenly Lord performed his arts: he filled his mouth with water and sprayed it upon the Patriarch’s face, whereupon the Patriarch awoke and bowed in thanks. The Heavenly Lord strode to the temple gates, let out a great shout, and brandished his command tablet. The Five Thunder Gods knelt before him. With a gesture toward the southern direction, he summoned forth five Thunder Lords—sharp-beaked, chicken-winged, wielding pointed hammers—who advanced. The five deities revealed their true forms, which were but five drums, now restrained by the Thunder Gods. The Heavenly Lord said, “I shall not keep these Five Thunders. Let them follow you to subdue demons.” The Patriarch rejoiced. The Heavenly Lord then returned to the Taihua Palace, while the Patriarch, now accompanied by the Five Thunders, journeyed onward.

They arrived at a place where a mountain called White Rock Mountain stood. Within it lay a cave named White Stone Cave.

Within the cave dwelled a demon, originally a brush once used by the Perfected Jiang that had attained spirit. It took the surname Tian and the given name Guai. Under its command were twelve lesser generals: the first named Mountain Demon, the second Water Monster, the third Stone Demon, the fourth Cliff Demon, the fifth Metal Demon, the sixth Wood Demon, the seventh Earth Demon, the eighth Fire Demon, the ninth Mud Demon, the tenth Sand Demon, the eleventh Human Demon, and the twelfth Star Demon. It possessed a dharma-treasure—a paper ledger of some thirty-odd pages—imbued with great numinous power. Whenever it encountered humans, it would unfurl the ledger, and the people would enter of their own accord, only to be carried into the cave and devoured. One day, Tian Guai emerged from the cave and chanced upon the Patriarch. Unprepared, the master and disciples were caught off guard when two of the demon’s underlings unfurled the ledger, trapping the entire company within. They were borne back to the cave, where Tian Guai rejoiced and ordered his minions to prepare a feast, intending to bring out the Patriarch and his followers to be cooked.

Hearing this, the captives were alarmed. Marshal Ma said, “Fear not. This ledger is made of paper, and I carry fire pellets. Ready your weapons and wait.” With that, Marshal Ma produced a fire pellet, while Marshal Zhou activated his wind wheel. The fire drew strength from the wind, and the wind fed the flames, setting the ledger ablaze. As it burned through, the company burst out, weapons in hand, and gave chase. Tian Guai fled with the ledger. Before the Patriarch, Marshal Deng, and Marshal Gao could emerge, they were swept away with the ledger by Tian Guai. The remaining marshals, unable to find the three, were deeply distressed. They conferred and decided to seek the Three Pure Ones, prostrating themselves to recount the events.

The Three Pure Ones listened and summoned the Heavenly Worthy of Wondrous Music to the hall. They said, “Your disciples now face peril, trapped within the ledger by Tian Guai and unable to escape. Their companions have come to seek aid. You must rescue them.” The Heavenly Worthy replied, “To free the three from the ledger, this object is the dharma-treasure of the Perfected Jiang. Only by requesting the Perfected Jiang’s presence can they be saved.” The Three Pure Ones said, “Then go swiftly with the marshals.”

The Heavenly Worthy took leave of the Three Pure Ones and ascended to the summit of White Rock Mountain. Entering the hermitage, he met the Perfected Jiang, who came forth to receive him with reverence. After the bows were exchanged, the Heavenly Worthy asked, “Is your dharma-treasure still in your possession?” The Perfected Jiang replied, “My dharma-treasure was entrusted to Tian Guai for safekeeping in the cave.” The Heavenly Worthy said, “If it remains there, bring it forth for me to see.” The Perfected Jiang entered the cave to search but found nothing. Greatly alarmed, he emerged to inform the Heavenly Worthy. The Heavenly Worthy smiled and said, “You tempered yourself through five hundred kalpas to obtain this treasure, yet you did not guard it with care. I have come precisely for this treasure of yours.” The Perfected Jiang said, “Since you have come for my treasure, you must know its whereabouts. I beg you to guide me in finding it.” The Heavenly Worthy replied, “The True Martial General of the North descended to the mortal realm by jade decree to subdue the black qi. Arriving at White Rock Mountain, he encountered Tian Guai, who opened your treasure and seized my disciples into the ledger. You remain unaware. Hasten now to rescue my disciples and retrieve the dharma-treasure, lest you violate the heavenly statutes.”

Hearing this, the Perfected Jiang was greatly shocked. He accompanied the Heavenly Worthy to the cave’s entrance and summoned Tian Guai. Upon learning of his master’s arrival, Tian Guai emerged with twelve demonic generals to greet the Perfected Jiang. At the sight of Tian Guai and his followers, the Perfected Jiang instantly revealed his true form—three-eyed, blue-faced, and fanged. With a single roar, the twelve demons reverted to their original shapes, and Tian Guai transformed back into his true form: a great brush, wailing in despair upon the ground. The Perfected Jiang cursed Tian Guai, then pointed at the paper ledger with his hand, extracting the Patriarch and the other two. Seizing Tian Guai, the Perfected Jiang reclaimed the dharma-ledger and commanded Tian Guai to submit to the Patriarch. Taking leave of the Heavenly Worthy, he returned to his cave. The Heavenly Worthy instructed Tian Guai to follow the Patriarch and perform the dharma, then parted ways to return to the Great Court. The Patriarch bestowed a pellet of Fire Elixir upon Tian Guai, who consumed it and continued along the path. What transpired thereafter shall be revealed in the following chapter.

---

**Chapter Four: The Patriarch Subdues the Sky-Obscuring Canopy**

The Patriarch bid farewell to the Perfected Jiang and the Heavenly Worthy, then journeyed with his marshals for a day until they reached a place called Purple Radiance Mountain. Within the mountain lay a cave named Yellow Sand Hollow, where a demon named Yu Tian resided. His form was that of a dragon’s body with a ghostly head, and he possessed a dharma-treasure called the Sky-Obscuring Canopy. With five thousand demonic soldiers, he frequently wreaked havoc before Purple Radiance Mountain, tormenting living beings. As the Patriarch and his company arrived at the mountain’s base, they saw a streak of demonic clouds approach. From within emerged a figure—ghost-headed and dragon-bodied—who brandished the Sky-Obscuring Canopy, casting it into the air. Instantly, all before them vanished from sight. The Patriarch and his followers were struck with alarm. In an instant, the canopy enveloped them, plunging them into the earth, leaving them unable to escape. Only Marshal Deng and Marshal Xin, who lagged behind, evaded capture. They fled upon the clouds to the Palace of Great Florescence, where they found the Heavenly Worthy of Wondrous Music and recounted the events.

The Heavenly Worthy said, “This is no ordinary treasure’s mischief—it is the work of the Sky-Obscuring Canopy of Marshal Zhang An of the Southern Heaven. You two need not despair. I shall accompany you to see Marshal Zhang and ask him to rescue your master.” With that, the three set off to the palace of Marshal Zhang. Finding him seated in meditation, the marshal rose to receive them and inquired as to their purpose. The Heavenly Worthy recounted the events in full. Marshal Zhang replied, “This is my fault. Heavenly Worthy, you need not descend to the mortal realm—I shall go with these two.” The Heavenly Worthy, greatly pleased, took leave of Marshal Zhang. The marshal then accompanied the two marshals upon the clouds, gazing down to see a lingering yellow cloud—none other than the Sky-Obscuring Canopy ensnaring the company. Marshal Zhang ordered Deng and Xin to descend and engage Yu Tian in battle. The two marshals obeyed, wielding their weapons as they advanced.

At the sight of them, Yu Tian rallied his lesser demons to fight. They clashed for three hundred rounds without victory or defeat. From the clouds, Marshal Zhang observed the battle, then raised his sword and exhaled a breath of water, revealing his true form—a Thunder Command Tablet. Grasping the tablet, he performed the dharma, reciting the true incantation and beckoning with his hand. The Sky-Obscuring Canopy stirred, revealing its true form: a yellow banner. Marshal Zhang seized it and tore it open, freeing the Patriarch and his disciples. Emerging from the canopy, the Patriarch questioned Marshal Zhang, and Marshals Deng and Xin recounted the events. Overjoyed, the Patriarch watched as Marshal Zhang released his grip, commanding Yu Tian to submit to the Patriarch.

Marshal Zhang returned to the heavenly court and memorialized the Jade Emperor. A decree arrived, appointing the Three Marshals as the Thunder Gate, with Deng, Xin, and Zhang as the Thunder Marshals. They were assigned to the Judgment Office of Xinjiang County, where Zhang An oversaw the Thunder Gate. The Patriarch rejoiced and bestowed Fire Elixir upon them. Another jade decree arrived, appointing Yu Tian as the Marshal for Subduing Demonic and Heretical Rain, wielding the Thunder Command Yellow Banner to remain ever at the Patriarch’s side, following his teachings. The Patriarch likewise bestowed Fire Elixir upon him, and the company continued on their journey.

They traveled until they reached a place called Black Tiger Mountain. Within the mountain dwelled two great spirits: one named Ren Wubie, the other Ning Shikua. They wielded a Moon Axe, wreaking havoc upon the mortal realm, seizing people into their cave to make meat buns for consumption.

One day, the Patriarch arrived at Black Tiger Mountain with his company. Upon seeing them, the two demons seized their axes and hurled them forth, transforming endlessly as they slashed. Marshal Ma, alarmed at the sight of the axes, immediately cast forth Fire Elixir, smelting the jade axes to fall to the ground. He then inverted his golden bell to cover them, capturing the two demons, and brought them before the Patriarch. The demons kowtowed, swearing allegiance. The Patriarch bestowed Fire Elixir upon them to consume. What transpired thereafter shall be revealed in the next chapter.

The Jade Emperor Dispatches an Envoy to Destroy a Village
The Patriarch, having gained Ren and Ning as his generals, rejoiced greatly. After traveling with his company for several days, they arrived at a place called Celestial Fire Mountain. Within the mountain dwelled a demon named Liu Hou, who wielded a flying whip and rode a fire chariot. Each year, the villagers below offered a boy and girl as sacrifices; if they failed to do so, Liu Hou would set fire to their homes. That year, the village head, Li Shan, had purchased a boy and girl from a poor family and was about to present them at the cave to sacrifice to Liu Hou. The children, ignorant of the ways of the world, wept bitterly at the temple gate, for their parents, having no money, had no choice but to sell them. As they wailed, the Patriarch and his company arrived before the temple. Inquiring into the matter, the children tearfully recounted their plight. The Patriarch was shocked. Marshal Ma, enraged upon hearing their tale, freed the children, seized his golden spear, and charged into the temple. There, he encountered Liu Hou, who came forth wielding his flying whip. The two clashed fiercely. Marshal Ma hurled his golden brick, striking Liu Hou to the ground, and brought him before the Patriarch. The Patriarch rejoiced. Liu Hou kowtowed, swearing allegiance, and the Patriarch took him in, bestowing Fire Elixir upon him to consume. A memorial was then sent to the Five Emperors, who appointed Liu Hou as Heavenly Lord of the Royal Court, wielding his flying whip and riding his fire chariot, to follow the Patriarch in the Dao.

One day, the Jade Emperor ascended his throne. The Hearth God of Ban Bamboo Village stepped forth and memorialized: “In Ban Bamboo Village, there are three hundred hearths, and the people all commit evil, living wickedly and acting abominably, showing no reverence for Heaven and Earth.” Enraged upon hearing this, the Jade Emperor decreed: “Approved. Summon Envoy of Pestilence, Zhong Shigui, to descend to the mortal realm and carry out the decree, exterminating the entire village of Ban Bamboo.” Shigui received the decree and departed the celestial court for the mortal realm, where the Earth God received him. The Pestilence God said: “The Five Emperors, upon hearing the memorial, were enraged. They declared that this village, which does not believe in goodness, must be destroyed. I have been sent to descend and carry out the decree. Tomorrow at the hour of *si*, you shall place this medicine into every well, so that all who drink the water shall perish from pestilence.” The Earth God replied: “The people here indeed do not believe in goodness and deserve destruction, but among them is one man, Lei Qiong, who makes his living selling tofu. He is kind-hearted, constantly cultivates good roots, and is generous in almsgiving. He must not be harmed.” The envoy said: “The good man shall be spared, but none others may be shown mercy.” He then handed the medicine to the Earth God.

The Earth God took the medicine, transformed into an old man, and waited by the well. Just then, Lei Qiong arrived to draw water for making tofu. The Earth God spoke from behind him: “Draw more of this water. Tomorrow at the hour of *si*, poison will be placed in it—whoever drinks it will die. Do not consume it.” Qiong turned to look but saw no one. Startled, he thought to himself: “If a divine being descends tomorrow to poison the well and destroy the entire village, how can I know of this and conceal it, preserving only my own life? Better that I die instead. If I can save the village, it will be my hidden merit.” The next day, as soon as dawn broke, he waited by the well to see if the words would prove true. Indeed, an old man approached, holding a packet of medicine, about to drop it into the well. Qiong rushed forward and seized it. The Earth God was alarmed and tried to snatch it back, but the old man swallowed it in one gulp. Instantly, he collapsed, his limbs turning black with pestilence. The Earth God, greatly shocked, carried the old man’s three *hun* and six *po* to the Heavenly Palace to see the Jade Emperor. The Jade Emperor, moved by the report, appointed Lei Qiong as Marshal of Majestic Pestilence. He was given a hat of the common people, a golden flower, and a golden plaque inscribed with the four characters “Unbound by Heaven or Earth,” allowing him to pass freely through the celestial gates and descend to assist the masters below. Lei Qiong thanked the Emperor and petitioned for the village’s pardon, which the Jade Emperor granted. Returning to Banzhu Village, Qiong appeared in the dreams of the villagers, urging them to reform and cultivate goodness. He then went to pay respects to his master. The master was overjoyed and led the group to another place—Shaanxi. There stood a mountain called Crimson Cloud Mountain, where a demon named Tian Wen dwelled, wreaking havoc. As the master and his company arrived, the Pestilence Marshal saw Tian Wen causing mischief and scattered the *Qiong* flower. Forged from the upright *qi* of Heaven and Earth, its presence dispelled all malevolent forces, revealing only a jade cup and an iron tube. Lei Qiong captured them and presented them to his master, who was greatly pleased and bestowed them upon him for his use.

Leaving Crimson Cloud Mountain, the group traveled onward until they reached a place called Spirit Screen Mountain. Within the mountain was a cave called Pure Seclusion Grotto, ruled by a demon named Shi Cheng. The demon wore a helmet like that of Erlang, his face pale with crimson lips, and wielded a thunder whip as his magical treasure, summoning the twelve earthly branches to aid him in battle. Deng, Xin, and Zhang arrived and, upon seeing him, hurled their own magical treasures. Shi Cheng, caught off guard, was captured and brought before the master. He kowtowed in submission. The master was delighted and wrote a memorial to the Jade Emperor, who issued a decree appointing him as Marshal of Divine Thunder and Stone, to follow the master’s command.

They journeyed further until they reached Gathering Tiger Mountain, where two demons lay in wait. One was named Wang Tie, pale-faced and wielding a long spear; the other was named Gao Tong, brandishing a pair of five-pronged axes. They often transformed into tigers by the mountain stream, dragging passersby up the mountain to devour at leisure. The master dispatched Zhao Shi to engage them in battle.

Marshal Zhao fought them for over nine hundred rounds, yet neither side gained the upper hand. Marshal Zhao cast his Fire Rope, while the white-faced Wang Tie hurled his Flying Spear, summoning the Divine Tiger of the Eastern Mountain to snatch at Marshal Zhao. Gao Tong then flung his Jade Axes, calling forth the Divine Tiger of the Western Mountain to join the fray. Marshal Zhao, unable to withstand the assault, fled in defeat. Upon witnessing this, Marshal Ma the Divine Official cast his Fire Elixir into the air, scorching the horde of demons until nine out of ten lay wounded, forcing them to flee behind their gates. Marshal Ma then cast his Golden Bell, trapping the two demons beneath it. They were seized and brought before the master, who rejoiced. He wrote a memorial to the Jade Emperor, who issued a decree appointing them as Marshal Wang of Tiger Hill and Marshal Gao the Second, to follow the master’s teachings.

What befell thereafter shall be revealed in the next chapter.

**Meng Shan Releases Prisoners onto the Daoist Path**

Now, the prison of Guangxi Prefecture held many convicts. Among them was a jailer named Meng Shan, who served in the prison. One year, on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, the prisoners wept bitterly within their cells, their mournful cries shaking the heavens. Meng Shan asked, “Why do you not weep on other days, yet today each of you wails so sorrowfully?” The prisoners replied, “Though we are not good men, we still hold a shred of filial piety. As the year draws to a close and we cannot see our parents, our longing grows unbearable, hence our tears.” Meng Shan said, “Your words move me to sorrow. I shall do you a kindness—let me release you to return home for the New Year. But on the fifth day of the first month next year, each of you must return without fail, lest you bring trouble upon me.” The prisoners bowed in gratitude, vowing earnestly before departing. When the first month of the following year arrived, they indeed returned and gathered, entering the prison once more. Meng Shan checked the prison register—all eight hundred were present—and rejoiced. From then on, every year on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, he would release the prisoners to return home, and they would come back on the fifth day of the first month, ever grateful for his virtue.

One day, Meng Shan said, “If you are willing to reform and become good men, I shall release you for good—what say you?” The prisoners replied, “If you, Warden, are willing to free us, how dare we return to our wicked ways? Yet though you save us all, your own life would be forfeit—how could we flee?” Meng Shan said, “If you truly reform and turn from evil to good, I have a way to escape my fate. Do not worry for me.” The prisoners, hearing this, bowed in thanks and gradually departed the prison, scattering to distant lands.

A month later, Prefect Teng Gongyi descended to the prison and found not a single soul. Shocked, he questioned Meng Shan. Meng Shan reported, “I released them, and they will return shortly.” The prefect flew into a rage, ordering Meng Shan to be flogged forty times and sent to retrieve the eight hundred prisoners. Bearing the punishment, Meng Shan took up a spear and left the prison. Arriving at a place called Tile Ridge Mountain, he planted his spear in the ground and sighed, “Though my superior punishes me today, I bear no resentment. To sacrifice my life to save eight hundred doomed souls—how could I regret it?” Just as he was about to impale himself on the spear, the Earth God transformed into a white hare and knocked the spear aside. Meng Shan lunged three times, and three times the white hare thwarted him. The Five Emperors, hearing of his plight, immediately dispatched the Floating Heaven Lord with a jade decree, appointing Meng Shan as Marshal Meng of Fengdu, to wear a commoner’s hat adorned with a golden flower, wield a Yellow Dragon Spear, and ride a cloud of azure. He was ordered to the northern lands to assist the master. Meng Shan entered court to give thanks, then paid his respects to the master, who rejoiced.

They journeyed onward until they reached a place called Chen Sand Land. There dwelled a demon named Yang Biao, who wrought havoc in the area, devouring people insatiably. Beneath the earth, he had dug countless pits; any traveler passing through at dusk would fall in, whereupon Yang Biao would seize and consume them. As the master and his generals advanced, they saw demonic clouds swirling, shrouding Chen Sand Land. The master said, “Ahead, demonic clouds rise—there must be a fiend within. Which of you generals dares to ride forth and subdue it?” Marshal Zhao charged forward at once, only to tumble into a stone pit, unable to battle Yang Biao. Seeing Marshal Zhao fall, the master was alarmed and strode forward with his sword to rescue him, only to fall into the pit himself. The Fire and Water Generals rushed forward and leapt in, carrying the master out. The Water General performed a spell, transforming into an inverse dragon that split the pit into a great river, allowing them to fight their way out. Seeing the pit collapse, the demon attempted to flee but was too late—Marshal Zhao seized him and brought him before the master. A jade decree arrived, appointing Yang Biao as Marshal of the Earth Spirits, to wield a warrior’s weapon and assist the master in his teachings. The master rejoiced and bestowed upon Yang Biao a Fire Elixir, which he consumed before joining their ranks.

Leaving Chen Sand Land, they arrived at a place called Dragon Gate Stockade, where a demon named Li Zhailong had conjured a barrier to block their path. Marshal Zhu cast his Five Poisons Bag, capturing the demon and bringing him before the master. A jade decree arrived, appointing him as Vanguard Marshal Li, to wield a bronze hammer, wear a helmet emblazoned with the character for "valor," and follow the master in vanquishing evil. Marshal Li gave thanks and paid his respects to the master, who bestowed upon him a Fire Elixir to consume.

What transpired thereafter shall be revealed in the following chapter.

The master’s journey to subdue evil at Mount Taibao continues. After departing Dragon Gate Grotto, the master arrived at Purple Clarity Cave, where a demon named Fu Ying barred their path. At his waist hung a magical treasure called the Demon-Illuminating Mirror—when tossed into the air, its flash would instantly daze all who beheld it. As the master and his company advanced, Fu Ying blocked their way. The generals brandished their weapons to seize him, but the demon hurled the mirror aloft. In an instant, the generals reeled, their vision blurred and heads spinning. Startled, the master charged forward himself, only for the demon to deploy the mirror once more. The master swiftly pointed his sword toward the south, summoning the fire of bing and ding to smelt the mirror, rendering it useless. Seizing the demon, the master accepted Fu Ying’s prostration and plea for surrender. He bestowed a Fire Elixir upon Fu Ying, who consumed it, then drafted a memorial to the Celestial Emperor. A jade decree arrived, appointing him as Inspector Vice Marshal, to follow the master in subduing evil.

The master then proceeded to a mountain called Mount Taibao, where thirteen demons wrought havoc, known as the Thirteen Taibao. Each year, they demanded twelve local children—six boys and six girls—as offerings, claiming countless lives. Their names were: Chao Wen, Wu Qing, Zhou Wang, Peng Gan, Fan Yi, Zhang Shen, Li Lu, Wang Li, Wu An, Liu Gang, Tian Neng, Shen You, and Zhu Li. Each possessed supernatural powers. When confronted by celestial soldiers, they needed only to strike their own bodies, and their foes would writhe in agony, easily captured.

On the fifth day of the fifth month, the Thirteen Taibao emerged for a leisurely outing, only to encounter the master’s company. Blocking their path, the demons met the generals, who charged forward to engage them. The demons struck their own bodies, and the generals cried out in pain. The Tortoise and Serpent Generals swiftly bore the master away, while Marshal Ma hastened to his aid. The master said, “Though I have escaped, these demons will surely pursue. What manner of beings are they, wielding such power?” Marshal Ma replied, “I believe only the Three Pure Ones can unravel this mystery.” The master and Marshal Ma immediately journeyed to the Three Clarities Temple, where they paid homage to the Three Pure Ones and recounted the events.

Master Miaole said, “These demons are no ordinary beings. Their progenitor, a deity now governing the southern and northern realms, is a man named Yin Gao. Only by summoning him can these demons be subdued.” The Three Pure Ones, having heard this, dispatched Master Miaole to the Water-Fire Mountain at the southern and northern border to seek Yin Gao.

Meanwhile, Yin Gao was stationed at Water-Fire Mountain, guarding the southern and northern border, when the perfected one arrived bearing a divine decree. He promptly emerged to receive the visitor, who, after formalities, said, “The Golden Tower’s incarnation has descended to the mortal realm to quell the black qi. Upon reaching Mount Taibao, he encountered a band of demons he could not subdue and sought the aid of the Three Pure Ones. By their decree, you are to assist the master without delay.” Yin Gao departed the southern and northern border and accompanied the master to Mount Taibao, where two demons—Yellow Pennant and Leopard Tail—blocked their path. Yin Gao sighed, “You wretches! I have not called upon you for ages, yet here you are, stirring up mischief!” He immediately performed a ritual, exhaling a killing qi that suffused the earth with golden light, revealing his true form as the Great Year Star—three-faced and four-armed. The two demons, unable to flee, exposed their true forms: two leopard tails from within a spear. Yin Gao seized them and, with the master, proceeded to the Taibao Stockade, where the Thirteen Taibao awaited.

Yin Gao engaged them in battle, but was soundly defeated and returned to the master. The master grew anxious, but Yin Gao said, “Do not fret, Master. Though I could not overcome them, my teacher, Master Sa, resides in the Southern Heavenly Grotto. If I beseech him, he will surely subdue these demons.” The master replied, “If you have such a teacher, hasten to seek his aid.” Yin Gao took his leave and journeyed to the Mystic Teaching Palace in the Southern Heavenly Grotto, where he found Master Sa seated in meditation. After paying his respects, Yin Gao was asked, “Disciple, why have you come in such haste?” Yin Gao recounted the events at Mount Taibao. Master Sa said, “Zhenwu is the Golden Tower’s incarnation. I shall accompany you to assist him, for no other could succeed.” With that, he gathered his magical treasures and, with Yin Gao, returned to the master. Their reunion brought great joy.

At dawn the next day, Yin Gao and Master Sa advanced to the battlefield, their war cries shaking the heavens. The Thirteen Taibao emerged in full armor to meet them. Just as they prepared to employ their magic against Yin Gao, Master Sa sprayed a mist from his Water-Containing Vessel and cast two ropes—one white, one red—into the air. The ropes ensnared the Thirteen Taibao, binding them into a single chain. Their true forms were revealed: thirteen skeletal remains. Master Sa placed a Fire Elixir within each skull and instructed Yin Gao, “Wear one skull upon your head and hang the remaining twelve around your neck. You shall follow the master in his teachings.” Yin Gao accepted the command, and the master expressed his gratitude. Master Sa then took his leave, ascending upon a cloud.

The Jade Emperor was memorialized, and his decree arrived, appointing Yin Gao as the Earthly Controller of Slaying the Malevolent Star, the Most Virtuous and Venerable Divine Marshal Yin, Commander of All Slaying Deities Under Heaven. Yin Gao expressed his gratitude and departed with his master. What transpired thereafter shall be revealed in the following chapter.

**Master Sa Subdues the Wicked King in Henan**

Now, there was a Perfected One named Sa Shoujian, who practiced medicine and saved the people. One day, he arrived in Henan and came upon a temple called the Temple of the Overseer. The temple deity was named Wang E, who each year on the sixth day of the sixth month demanded that the local people prepare ten sheep, ten oxen, ten pigs, and ten jars of wine for his festival. If they failed, he would spread pestilence to harm the people. The village elders, driven to poverty, pawned their wives and sold their sons and daughters—truly a pitiful sight.

Upon learning of this, the Perfected One set fire to the temple and burned it to the ground. Seeing the divine radiance of the Perfected One, Wang E dared not resist and fled. After burning the temple, Sa Shoujian departed for Huizhou.

Wang E then commanded his lesser demons to spread pestilence. Alas, in one village, nine out of ten households fell ill. At night, he appeared in the dreams of the villagers, demanding that they rebuild his temple. If they refused, he threatened to set their houses ablaze. The people lived in constant dread.

One day, Wang E went out and saw a family named Sun, whose daughter, a maiden of eighteen named Qianjin, was exceedingly beautiful. That night, he transformed into a young man and seduced the girl. After more than a month, Qianjin was no longer recognizable as herself. Her family was deeply distressed.

One day, the Patriarch arrived in Henan and sought lodging at the Sun household. Seeing Sun Shou’s gloom, the Patriarch asked, “We are mendicants, seeking shelter for the night before continuing our journey tomorrow. Why does the elder seem so troubled?”

Sun Shou replied, “It is not that I am displeased with your stay. I have a matter weighing on my heart.” The master asked, “What is it?” Sun Shou said, “I have a daughter, eighteen years of age, who has been bewitched by some ghost. He claims to possess divine powers, and this has left me deeply troubled.”

The Patriarch grew furious upon hearing this and said to Sun Shou, “This poor monk shall capture this demon for you, in repayment for your kindness.” Before he could finish speaking, a fierce wind arose, and in midair appeared a man nine feet tall, his face black as iron, brandishing a golden whip.

Sun Shou exclaimed, “That is the one!” The Patriarch immediately ordered Marshal Ma to engage him in battle. Huaguang received the command, wielding his master’s spear, and ascended into the clouds, cursing, “You vile demon, dismount and surrender at once! If you are brought before the Heavenly Court, you may yet live. Refuse, and your life shall be forfeit in an instant!”

Wang E flew into a rage and swung his whip to strike. The two fought in midair for over three hundred rounds without either gaining the upper hand. Wang E then revealed his divine power, hurling his golden whip into the air, from which countless whips rained down. Marshal Ma responded by tossing his golden brick. They fought for another fifty rounds, still evenly matched.

The Patriarch drew his sword to join the battle. Wang E, his strength waning, could no longer resist. He withdrew his whip and fled in defeat. Huaguang unleashed his fire chariot, fire crows, and fire elixirs in pursuit. The Patriarch pointed his sword, and the demon transformed into a streak of golden light, fleeing toward Huizhou Prefecture.

There, he encountered Sa Shoujian, who was performing a ritual. Seeing Wang E, the Perfected One grew enraged and declared, “This demon dares to appear here again!” He raised his command tablet, recited an incantation, and the demon could not escape. Sa Shoujian captured him and ordered a heavenly general to escort Wang E to the Patriarch.

The heavenly general brought Wang E before the Patriarch, saying, “This official knew you had descended to subdue the dark qi, so I have brought this general to submit to you.” The Patriarch was pleased. He gave Wang E a fire elixir to consume and wrote a memorial to the Jade Emperor. The imperial decree arrived, appointing him Marshal Huoluo Wang and bestowing upon him a golden tablet inscribed with the words “Loyal and True of Heart.” He was to obey the laws and follow the master’s teachings. Wang E expressed his gratitude.

The Patriarch said, “Your nature is most unyielding. Now that you have turned to goodness, if you do not change your former ways, how can you bear the words ‘Loyal and True of Heart’? Should your heart remain insufficient, the Jade Emperor will hold you accountable, and by then, regret will be too late.”

Wang E laughed heartily and replied, “A true man’s word can revive a nation. To know one’s faults and correct them is to be a good man. How could there be any hesitation? This humble general, having been taken in by the master, from this day forward, will accept no bribes and show no favoritism. If anyone follows my teachings, I shall protect them. If anyone extorts money from the people, I shall strike them dead.”

The Patriarch smiled and said, “Your words are just, but you must also take compassion as your foundation.” Marshal Wang respectfully acknowledged the command.

The Patriarch then addressed his assembled followers, “I descended from the Heavenly Court over thirty years ago. The dark qi across the land has nearly been subdued. Last night, I observed carefully and saw that only in the West does a demonic cloud linger, refusing to disperse.”

He turned to Marshal Zhu and instructed, “There remains a demonic cloud in the West that will not dissipate. Take the Five Poisons Bag and subdue it completely before returning.” Marshal Zhu received the order and set forth for the West. He cast the Five Poisons Bag into the air, but the dark qi could not be contained.

Returning, they reported these events to the Patriarch. The Patriarch then went with all his generals, each casting their dharma treasures into the air, but the qi surged even more fiercely.

The Patriarch said, “What can be done about this?” He resolved, “I shall go and consult my master, the Wondrous Joy Heavenly Worthy, to devise another plan.”

Having spoken, he went to see the Wondrous Joy Heavenly Worthy. The Heavenly Worthy asked, “Why have you come?”

The Patriarch replied, “This disciple descended to the mortal realm to subdue the dark qi, and now it is nearly all gathered. Only in the West does a lingering black cloud refuse to disperse. My disciples and I cannot subdue it, so I have come to seek your guidance.”

The Heavenly Worthy said, “That black qi is an evil star, now trapped within the heavens of the Buddhist teachings. It cannot escape, and thus is difficult to subdue. Only with the aid of a perfected Buddhist disciple can it be gathered.”

The Patriarch asked, “Where might such a disciple be found?”

The Heavenly Worthy replied, “To the west, on Snow Mountain, there is a prince who practices with utmost devotion. He is the son of King Chu and has now achieved success. You must first go to Flame Lamp Buddha to receive the prediction and become a disciple of the Buddhist teachings. Then, entrust Flame Lamp Buddha to summon the prince of Snow Mountain. Only then can the black qi within the heavens of the Buddhist teachings be subdued.”

The Patriarch bowed in gratitude, took leave of the Heavenly Worthy, and descended to the mortal realm. He instructed Marshal Deng and the others to wait in the world below while he, accompanied by Marshal Ma, went to the West to pay homage to Flame Lamp Buddha.

Upon seeing the Patriarch and Marshal Ma, Flame Lamp Buddha asked, “Limitless-Prime, you have paid homage to countless buddhas, and Marshal Ma is the manifestation of Mañjuśrī Tathāgata from the Western Paradise of Ultimate Bliss. Why have you come here?”

The Patriarch replied, “This disciple’s spiritual powers are meager, and I have come to pay respects to my revered master.”

Flame Lamp Buddha said, “You are a disciple of the Wondrous Joy Heavenly Worthy and an emanation of the Golden Portal. Why would you bow to this humble monk as your master?”

The Patriarch replied, “To return to the true fruit, one must practice the Way of the Fifty-Three Visits.”

After receiving the Patriarch’s bow, Flame Lamp Buddha smiled and said, “Disciple, though you bow before me, I know you have come because of the star’s qi in the West. For this matter, I must summon the prince of Snow Mountain, and only then can this qi be eradicated.”

Flame Lamp Buddha then commanded Mañjuśrī and Samantabhadra to go and fetch the prince. Mañjuśrī and Samantabhadra said, “He is but a mortal cultivating the Way. How can we be certain of his attainment? How can we lightly summon him?”

The Buddha smiled and said, “Since you two do not believe, I shall transform something to test him, and then you will see.”

The two received the command and departed. Mañjuśrī transformed into an eagle, and Samantabhadra into a sparrow. They arrived at Snow Mountain, where the prince sat in pure meditation upon his altar. Mañjuśrī, as an eagle, swooped down to seize the sparrow, which fled into the prince’s embrace. The eagle pursued and, speaking in human words, said, “I was hunting that sparrow, and you have taken it into your arms. Now I must eat what you have saved. Will you offer your flesh to me?”

The prince replied, “If you are hungry and wish to eat my flesh, there is no knife here to cut it. Go and fetch a sharp bamboo, and I will cut my flesh for you.”

Hearing this, the eagle flew away. It then transformed into a tiger, chasing a white rabbit, which again sought refuge with the prince. Seeing this, the prince once more sheltered the rabbit within his altar. The tiger, speaking in human words, said, “You have saved it, and now I shall starve. You cannot save both.”

The prince replied, “The rabbit is too small to satisfy your hunger. Go below, and I shall fall to you.”

The tiger complied and waited below. The prince cast himself down from the altar. In an instant, heavenly flowers blanketed the earth, and a golden lotus arose, bearing the prince to the Western Paradise, where he entered to see Flame Lamp Buddha. After receiving the prediction and paying homage, he met the Patriarch.

The Patriarch said, “I beg you, elder brother, to accompany me below to subdue the demon. There will be a great reward.”

The prince replied, “This humble monk has only just entered the Western Paradise and possesses no spiritual powers. How can I assist others?”

Flame Lamp Buddha said, “The Patriarch is an emanation of the Golden Portal. You may accompany him below to gather the black qi and return. It will not be too late to attend the sutra teachings in the Central Heaven.”

The prince bowed in gratitude and descended with the Patriarch to the mortal realm, where they met the assembled generals. At dawn the next day, the Patriarch and the prince arrived at the western frontier. The air resounded with their battle cries as they called for the demon to surrender.

Suddenly, the demonic cloud appeared before them, and from within emerged a monk, who called himself the Iron-Headed General.

The Patriarch said, “I see you are tonsured and robed, with prayer beads around your neck. You must be one from the heavens. Why have you descended to the mortal realm, unleashing black qi to harm the people below?”

The monk replied, “I remain in my own place. You have come seeking me, not I you.”

He swung his iron alms bowl at the Patriarch, who met the attack with his sword. The Patriarch could not overcome the demon and was about to press forward when the demon, sensing the true qi, fled into the Iron Robe Cave. The Patriarch rallied his generals, and they pursued, tightly besieging the cave entrance. Each general cast their dharma treasures into the cave, but none could harm the demon.

The prince struck his skull drum, and the demon within the cave grew dizzy and disoriented. Stumbling out, he was seized by Marshal Li and brought before the Patriarch. The demon refused to submit.

Marshal Ma said, “This wretched creature will not yield. Iron belongs to the metal class, and fire can overcome metal. I shall burn this wretch to death.”

The demon laughed, “How amusing, how amusing! Burn me clean if you will—I shall never submit to you.”

The generals then said, “Since fire cannot consume him, iron must fear clay. Order the Clay Star to transform into a mound of yellow earth, with fire raging within, and cast the monk into it.”

Upon hearing this, the demon sighed, “Do not do so—I yield, I yield!”

Greatly pleased, the Patriarch bestowed upon him a Fire Elixir pellet to swallow. He then sent the prince back to the heavenly courts to attend the Flame Lamp Buddha and listen to the sutras. A jade decree arrived, appointing the demon as the Fierce Iron Marshal, wielding an iron staff to follow the Patriarch in the Dao. But what transpired later? Tune in to the next chapter for the unfolding tale.

The Patriarch Gains the Thunder Gods as Disciples

The Patriarch departed the western lands and journeyed onward until he reached Stone Thunder Mountain, where legions of thunder gods dwelled, often appearing before mortals: the Five Directions’ Thunder Duke Generals, the Eight Directions’ Cloud-Thunder Envoys, the Five Directions’ Rain-Thunder Envoys, and the Thunder Division’s Marshal of Thunder.

At the foot of this mountain lived an elder named Shi Yuan, who had two daughters—one sixteen, the other fourteen—eating at home one day. As they sliced a winter melon, they tossed its seeds and pulp into the ditch beneath the kitchen stove. A Thunder Envoy, spying this from midair, mistook the refuse for rice and condemned the girls for their wastefulness. Instantly, he unleashed the Thunder Duke, who struck the two sisters dead.

Upon closer inspection, the Thunder Duke saw they were melon seeds, not rice, and regretted his haste. He brought the matter before the Thunder Envoy, who said, “What’s done is done. We shall turn this error to purpose—I shall guide you both to the Heavenly Lord.”

“What are your names?” he asked.

The girls replied, “I am called Zhu Peiniang, and my younger sister is Zhu Beiniang.”

The Thunder Envoy said, “I shall now initiate you two sisters. I grant you two Thunder-Electric Mirrors to keep and wield, and you shall be called Shadow-Blade Ladies. When I strike a person, you shall first release lightning to illuminate them clearly. To Zhu Beiniang, I give a skull and a fan, and you shall be called Moon Comet Lady, for when you strike, none can move.”

The two sisters received their orders without further remark.

Now, the Patriarch arrived at Stone Thunder Mountain, where he heard the roar of thunder and saw flashes of lightning. He stepped forward and pointed with his sword, shouting loudly. All the Thunder Envoys emerged and, upon seeing the Patriarch, knelt before him. The Patriarch asked the reason, and the Thunder Envoys replied, “We brothers could not bear to part, so the Jade Emperor commanded us to undergo tribulation here.”

The Patriarch asked, “Will you submit to me?”

The Thunder Envoys said, “We brothers have no one to rely on, and we have heard that the Patriarch is the incarnation of the Golden Portal. How dare we not obey?”

The Patriarch, greatly pleased, said, “Since you are willing to submit to me, I shall enlist you as generals under my command. As you brothers cannot bear separation, you shall thunder in the south during spring and summer, and in the north during autumn and winter, thus preserving your fraternal bond.”

The Thunder Envoys, overjoyed, bowed in gratitude and pledged their allegiance. The Patriarch memorialized the Jade Emperor, who issued a decree: Zhu Peiniang was appointed Thunder Mother of the Thunder Department, and Zhu Beiniang was named Moon Comet Heavenly Lord. From the northeastern celestial realm, the Patriarch summoned Wind Master and Rain Master, entrusting them with the Wind and Rain Talismans to accompany him in his teachings. The Thunder Duke was appointed Great General of the Nine Heavens’ Thunderclap.

The Patriarch rejoiced. Seeing that the dark qi of the middle realm had dissipated and the people lived in peace, he led his generals into the Thirty-Three Heavens to pay homage to the Jade Emperor and report the events. The Jade Emperor was greatly pleased and granted the Patriarch a seat beside him on an embroidered stool.

The Jade Emperor said, “Now that the dark qi is fully dispelled, you may take your generals to guard the Southern Heavenly Treasure Virtue Pass. Do not delay, lest demons descend to disturb the lower realm.”

The Patriarch expressed his gratitude. The Five Emperors further bestowed upon him the titles Supreme Primordial Jade Void Master-Preceptor, Mysterious Heavenly Emperor, and Heavenly Worthy of Subduing Demons. He was placed in command of thirty-six heavenly generals, and every year on the twenty-fifth day of the twelfth month, he would descend with his generals to inspect the good and evil of the world. The Jade Emperor presented him with two cups of Golden Wave Celestial Wine and personally escorted him from the palace.

The Patriarch expressed his thanks, assembled his generals, and assumed his post. A grand banquet was held to reward the troops, and they took up their stations at the Heavenly Gate to receive the incense offerings of all beings. Thus, the Eternal Buddha was revered.

The Patriarch once more descended to the mortal realm to relieve suffering.

Now, in the Yangzi River near Mount Wudang, there dwelled a water-snail spirit, a horse spirit, a snail spirit, and a bamboo-rope spirit. Seeing the Patriarch in the mortal realm, these spirits dared not cause trouble.

Upon hearing of the Patriarch’s ascent to Heaven, the spirits stirred waves in the river, harming travelers and merchants, their grievances rising to the skies. The Patriarch, observing from Baode Pass, grew enraged and declared, “To cut the grass and remove the roots. I descended to the mortal realm for four years, sweeping away the dark qi. Yet these four demons still lurk in the rivers and mountains. Now, seeing me ascend, they dare to wreak havoc again. As the ancient saying goes, ‘If the grass is cut but the roots remain, new shoots will sprout.’”

At once, he performed a ritual, manifesting eighty-two transformations. Leaving one incarnation to guard Baode Pass alongside the marshals, his true form departed the heavens and descended straight to Mount Wudang to save the people. Arriving at the Yangzi River’s edge, the Patriarch worked his magic, summoning the Threefold True Fire to dry the waters. Seeing the river parched, the spirits rolled ashore—only to find the Patriarch standing there, wielding the Seven-Star Sword in ritual. At the sight of him, they fled. The Patriarch gave chase, and before ten rounds of combat had passed, all were slain. Only the snail spirit and bamboo-rope spirit escaped, their whereabouts unknown. Deeply troubled, the Patriarch returned to the celestial court, where he oversaw the marshals guarding the Heavenly Gate. He dispatched another incarnation to descend once more, stationing it at Mount Wudang to suppress the two remaining spirits and aid the people. Whenever official vessels faced peril on the river, the Patriarch would appear in midair, hair unbound and sword in hand, to rescue them. The dragon kings of the Five Lakes and Four Seas came to pay homage, while officials and merchants were frequently saved.

A statue of the Patriarch was sculpted at the foot of Mount Wudang, and a temple was built to enshrine him. In a dream, the Patriarch instructed the people to craft thirty-six celestial generals, each wielding a demon-subduing Seven-Star Sword, treading upon a coiling serpent and the Eight Trigrams Tortoise. Whenever officials or commoners sailed past, the Patriarch would manifest to protect them, ensuring their safety. Those passing by the river would enter the temple to burn incense, and the sacred flames never ceased.

In the third year of the Yongle Emperor’s reign, the Yellow-Haired Tartars rebelled. The sovereign was alarmed and dispatched troops to meet them, only to suffer a crushing defeat. At the height of the crisis, a figure suddenly appeared in midair, sword in hand, accompanied by thirty-six celestial generals. They unleashed wind, thunder, and swarms of wasps, charging forward to slay the Tartar chieftains Dalicing, Dalihe, Gaomuer, and Dengjiahu. The Yongle Emperor, unaware of the deity’s identity, returned victorious to the court. He sent envoys to the Supreme Clarity Palace to summon the Heavenly Master Zhang.

The sovereign inquired, “When I clashed with the Tartars, I was defeated in battle. At the moment of greatest peril, a deity appeared in the sky—hair unbound, sword in hand, with a fair complexion and long beard—leading thirty-six celestial generals, accompanied by a tortoise and serpent, charging from the north to save my life. The Tartars were slain, and I returned to the court. I wish to repay this deity’s kindness, but I do not know which god it was. That is why I have summoned you today; surely you recognize him.”

The Heavenly Master replied, “The one with unbound hair and the tortoise and serpent is none other than the True Sovereign Emperor of the Northern Dao.”

Overjoyed, the sovereign asked, “You say this is the Dark Heaven Sovereign. Where is his temple now?”

The Heavenly Master answered, “This deity attained enlightenment on his own, aiding all people. He rescues those in disaster and saves those in peril. Travelers on the river are all saved by him. The merchants long ago built a temple at the foot of Mount Wudang.”

The sovereign declared, “Even the common people know to repay kindness. My life and this realm owe everything to this deity. How could I forget? Since you say the original temple stands at Mount Wudang, I shall personally lead a procession there to burn incense and behold his likeness, building a temple to repay his grace.”

He issued an edict, commanding the civil and military officials, along with the Heavenly Master, to accompany him to Mount Wudang by the Yangzi River. The sovereign entered the temple to burn incense, and upon seeing the Patriarch’s statue—so like the figure he had witnessed—his heart swelled with joy. After the rites, he returned to the court and hosted a grand banquet for all officials.

He then decreed that General Jin supervise the construction, with the Marquis of Longping leading thirty thousand laborers and craftsmen to Mount Wudang. There, they built a golden hall, gilded the Patriarch’s statue, and erected thirty-six halls and seventy-two palaces. Lu Ban descended to assist, and within a year, the halls, palaces, and statues were complete. Generals Jin and the Marquis of Longping returned to the court to report the completion.

The sovereign was overjoyed and promoted General Jin three ranks. He selected forty-eight virtuous Daoist masters from across the land to serve as Daoist officials. The sovereign then ordered the Heavenly Master to conduct a seven-day, ten-night grand ritual, during which he would personally burn incense and pay homage.

The Marquis of Longping stepped forward and petitioned, “Your Majesty has now built the temple and sculpted the deity’s statue, fully demonstrating your sincerity. However, I fear that in the future, those who come to burn incense may lack the means to make offerings, and the stellar officials may go without sustenance. This is not a sustainable plan. I beg Your Majesty to bestow your boundless compassion and allocate funds from some source to ensure the eternal continuity of the sacred flames.”

The sovereign, greatly pleased, issued a decree granting five hundred *qing* of incense and lamp fields, along with one hundred *qing* of wheat and rice fields. Any damage to the temple was to be repaired, ensuring the sacred flames would burn for ten thousand generations.

As the sovereign prepared to feast with his ministers at Mount Wudang, a report came that a bell had floated up from the river, drifting ashore. The sovereign ordered it retrieved and brought into the great hall. It was a bronze bell cast from seven treasures, its sound carrying for a hundred *li*.

The sovereign, upon witnessing this, was overjoyed. He promptly departed Mount Wudang, ordering his procession to return to the capital with his assembled civil and military officials. The ancestral master of Mount Wudang displayed his mighty spiritual power, delivering those in distress and rescuing those in peril. The four seas grew calm, their waves stilled, and the people felt the grace of the deity. Filial sons and obedient grandsons who prayed for their parents, or those without children who sought heirs—none failed to receive divine response. His fame spread throughout the two capitals and the thirteen provinces, and those who came to burn incense and pray for blessings were beyond counting. The devout might find bolts of crimson silk drifting down from the heavens, draping themselves upon their bodies—a sign known as "receiving the silken blessing." People from all corners of the realm, men and women, young and old, came in throngs, some prostrating with every step, all chanting the Buddha of Infinite Life. Every prayer met with a response. For over two hundred years since, the sacred flames have burned as brightly as ever, and the mountain has remained an eternal site of imperial veneration. The realm enjoys unbroken peace.

chunks.original_text: 《北游记》 明 余象斗 编着 《北游记》又名《北方真武祖师玄天上帝出身志传》，余象斗编着 卷 一 玉帝设宴会群臣 却说隋朝炀帝临天下。 忽一日，玉帝降下玉旨，在三十三天兜率宫设宴，会浮天君、张天君、许天君、立天君、葛天君等。 众天君得旨，各各依次而到。 朝见山呼毕，玉帝曰：“孤立极有五百劫，昼夜勤劳。 细观孤之中天，不如西方之万一。 今会卿等，欲图一路而得往西方境界，脱离劫数，听佛说法，则孤万无忧也。 欲行不能，今会卿等能代孤设得一路者，卿之功也。 ”众真君奏曰：“在凡修仙七世，并无破戒，方为陛下。 在凡入道九世，先要破戒，方转西方。 陛下原是修仙，安能入得西方？ 欲脱生死，不免去凡胎出家修行，方能成佛。 如其不然，则不能也。 ”玉帝闻奏，不觉放声长叹，便有思降之意。 忽见对面有一金花树，毫光灿灿，有金花起。 玉帝问曰：“前面是什么毫光闪闪，令人可爱。 ”葛天君出班奏曰：“此非别物，乃是南方巽宫九重天外，刘天君家内，有一金花树，其名曰接天树。 其树能聚诸宝贝，此是宝光起，方才有金光照耀。 ”玉帝闻奏，即宣南方火德君进朝，命去刘天君家讨此天树。 众臣退朝，星君谢恩出朝，直往南方巽宫刘天君家讨接天树不题。 却说刘天君正坐之间，忽见使到，接入坐下。 刘天君问曰：“使命大人至此，有何旨意？ ”星君曰：“圣上设宴，忽见贵宅宝树，毫光闪闪，圣上爱之，命下官造府，要讨此物。 ”刘天君曰：“要此安敢不从？ 但吾世代接续有此树，树中有七宝常时而出。 圣上若要此树，恐动之，七宝散去，不会有光，又恐不发。 其实无用。 烦使命大人回奏玉帝，免致害却此物可也。 ”使命闻言告退，回奏玉帝，奏明前事。 玉帝闻奏，大怒言曰：“吾为一天之主，倒不及刘天君家有此树，能生七宝，光现照人，妙不可言。 ”又问众臣曰：“其树要何人常得享用？ ”众臣奏曰：“此树惟有刘天君家子孙方得管理享用。 ”帝闻奏。 忽然失声叹曰“如何能得到他家做个子孙，得享用此物，孤心足矣！ ”众臣听罢玉帝之言，个个大惊，出班奏曰：“圣人不乱言。 圣上既出此言，必当改位投胎。 ”玉帝心意，只想那接天树，不顾降生之苦，亦答曰：“依卿之言，孤去则谁为主？ ”众臣又奏曰：“陛下三魂化身，当指一魂化身，去降生投胎。 ”玉帝闻奏，听说要他三魂指一魂去，不觉下泪。 众臣奏曰：“陛下圣言一出，安可食之？ 无信不立，陛下宜速发旨。 ”玉帝曰：“虽孤今日指一魂化身降生，何日完之？ ”众臣奏曰：“陛下勿忧。 功成完满，依旧还原。 ”玉帝只得指一魂化身，众臣各起一道金光，直送往刘天君家去降生不题。 却说刘天君与红莲公主在后花园赏玩，偶见一道金光自天心而降，内有四门天王、八大金刚、九条青龙随行，捧一个金盘，盘内捧着一个孩儿前来，直到园中。 公主问刘天君曰：“此是什物？ ”刘天君曰：“必是一大贵人有难，欲投胎托生者，我与夫人当拜之。 ”公主听夫之言，即焚点好香，二人虔诚礼拜。 只见金光渐渐而近，投入公主怀中。 刘天君大喜，望空拜谢。 不过一月，红莲公主有孕，说与天君得知，天君大喜，言曰：“既是有孕，其孕必是贵人也。
